title: February 2024/20.24.2 Release Highlights Video

captions.text: This video is a selection of the new and updated features
we're excited to share with you from the February 2024 Release.
The full list of features can be found in the February 2024 Version 20.24.2 Release Notes,
which you can find on Brightspace Community.
This month we’re highlighting the following features:
Brightspace – Branded footer on main pages
Data Hub – Brightspace Data Sets improvements for February
Discover – Perform bulk actions on enrollment requests
And finally, a Summary of Changes made for all the other features.
Let’s take a closer look at this month’s features!
With this release, a Powered by D2L Brightspace footer now appears
on select pages in Brightspace. The footer appears on the following pages:
D2L’s login pages, Org and org unit homepages, Portfolio, Brightspace for Parents and Guardian,
Discover, Manager Dashboard and finally, Insights Portal Dashboard.
This update replaces the footer that previously appeared at the bottom of
the login page and removes the corresponding Do not display
D2L branded footer setting from the Login Page Management tool.
This feature is available to all clients,
is automatically enabled, and is not dependent on any configuration variables or permissions.
Note that when customers use their own login pages, users do not see the D2L Footer.
For more information about this update,
refer to the Powered by D2L blog post in Brightspace Community.
In Data Hub, the following Brightspace Data Sets (BDS) are available in this release:
In the Course Copy Log BDS a new StatusId column is added.
In the LTI Links BDS new LastModifiedBy and IsDeleted columns are added.
Also, in the LTI Links BDS the Url column size is changed from 1000 to 2000.
Also in Data Hub, the following Brightspace Data Sets (BDS) are no longer available:
LTI Links Shared and Survey Question Answer Options
This feature is available to all clients.
To enable ensure the Can Access Brightspace Data Sets permission
is granted to administrators at the org level.
Also, Ensure the d2l.Tools.BrightspaceDataSets.Version
configuration variable is set to version 8.13 or 9.2
Note that new and changed data sets appear the first
time the data set runs after the version update.
Users with the appropriate role permissions, (approvers) can now perform bulk actions on
enrollment requests in Discover.Approvers can:
Select and process multiple enrollment requests simultaneously,
including options to approve or decline enrollment requests.
When declining an enrollment request,
approvers can also send a single comment to all users whose requests have been declined.
This feature also introduces a new Delete Enrollment Requests
permission. With this permission, users can:
Delete individual or multiple Approved, Pending, or Declined enrollment requests.
Previously, approvers were limited to handling one enrollment request at a time, without the
capability to approve, decline, delete, or comment on multiple requests concurrently.
Note that deleting an Approved request does not unenroll a user from the related course.
If an approver deletes a pending or declined enrollment request,
learners can request enrollment again, if that course is visible in Discover.
Also, it is important to note that Approvers cannot restore deleted
enrollment requests. Learners are not notified when an approver deletes an enrollment request.
Therefore, D2L recommends that approvers notify users of any deleted enrollment requests.
Select multiple enrollment requests,
then choose to Approve, Decline, or Delete all selected requests.
You can send a single comment when declining multiple requests.
This feature is available to all clients.
To approve or decline enrollment requests,
users must have the Approve Enrollment Requests permission.
To delete enrollment requests, users must have the Delete Enrollment Requests permission.
Also, note again that deleted enrollment requests cannot be restored.
Finally, let’s take a quick look at the other features for this month’s release.
Bongo – Provide tailored feedback using Learning
Outcomes with AI Coaching and Smart Scoring features
and, Question Library – Removal of the question mark icon
We hope you enjoyed this month’s release highlights.
As before, you can get the full details of this month’s changes in the February
2024 / Version 20.24.2 Release Notes which you can find on Brightspace Community.
See you next month!

title: Options for Randomizing Quizzes | Instructor

captions.text: In this video we will explore the different ways you can randomize quizzes within Brightspace.
There are several options that can be used,
including a random selection of questions from a question pool,
allowing access to all questions but shuffling the order of the questions appear for each learner,
and lastly shuffling the answer order from all the choice questions.

This video will go into detailabout how to set up each of these options and give you the information you need to determine which option or
options will work best for you.
Before we begin, you should note that the question library is an important part of this process.
The question library is a central repository where you can store questions to reuse in a course.
As a best practice, it is recommended that you create all your questions using the question library.
This ensures your questions areorganized and stored in one central location for reuse and access.
To give a random selection of questions within a question pool, the questions you want to include have to be located within the question library depending on how large the pool of questions are.
For example, if the settings required 10 questions from a pool of 100 questions, and you have 8 learners that will take the quiz,
it's possible that each learner will receive completely different quiz questions from one another.
From within your course, access the question library from the Quizzes page and by selecting the Question Library tab.
From here you can click on the New button to create your question types or you can create a section which is like a folder of questions.
Once you have your questions andare ready to create your quiz,
go back to the main quiz areaand select New Quiz.
Enter your quiz name and then select the Create New button, choosing Question Pool.
You'll give your question pool a title and now you want to click on the Browse Question Library button.
This will open up your question library and you can then select the questions that you wish to use in this quiz.
Select the Import button and the total number will populate and you can then add in the number of questions that you wish to poll, for example 2 questions.
After you're ready, click on the save button and now your questions will be available within the quiz setup.
An alternative option would beto use sections instead of the question pool.
This allows you to shuffle some questions while still being able to omit those questions that you want to be sure every learner has access to.
To set this up, follow the same steps for creating a question pool, but instead choose Create New and Section.
Give the section a title.
You can select to hide this title from your learners as well as the text if desired.
And finally, you can select the shuffle questions in this section so that any questions that are brought in here will be shuffled for every user who takes the quiz.

Once you've completed entering your information, you can hit the save button and then you can either create new quiz questions for this section by going to create New, or you can add existing questions from your question library.
Once you've uploaded your questions from the library, you can drag them into the section and now any questions that are within this section will be shuffled.
If you're not using sections to house your questions, you can still add them in and shuffle them from the quiz level.
Once you have your questions, select Timing and Display and then choose Shuffle questions and sections within the quiz.
Lastly, another simple option is to randomize the order that answers are listed for multiple choice questions within a quiz.
To do this, open up your multiple choice question and you will see the randomized answer order at the bottom.

Do be cautious for questions such as this where you are identifying all the above or two specific answers, because if you randomize these well then your order might not account for the answer that you have listed.
Thanks for watching and hopethat you found these tips helpful.

title: Brightspace Virtual Assistant | Learner

captions.text: This video explains how to use Brightspace Virtual Assistant as a learner.
Brightspace Virtual Assistant provides answers to your questions by directing you to written, video, and real-time support.
Open Brightspace Virtual Assistant by clicking on the icon.
Click on a custom button to be directed to common questions and answers; or enter a question in the search field.
Your question is answered with Brightspace Community article results.
Click Read article to open the article.
Scroll through the content to receive textual and video support.
Note, however, that video walkthroughs are not prevalent in all Community articles.
If you can’t find your answer in the suggested article, below Still need help?, the following buttons can help you with your search:
Yes, I have another question: Lets you enter a new question.
Ask the Community: Directs you to the Brightspace Community landing page.
Contact Support: Provides you with support options according to your organization’s EUS package.
Or simply enter a new question into the search field.

title: Create and Enroll a User | Administrator

captions.text: This video demonstrates how to create and enroll users in an org unit.
Enroll users in org units to define their access and role throughout different levels of your organization.
In the Classlist tool of the org unit where you want to add a user, click Add Participants > Create and enroll a new user.
Enter the user’s information in the required fields.
The asterisk shows you which fields are mandatory.
Include an email so the new user can be notified via email of their enrollment.
You can also select Force password change on login if you want the user to change their password when they first log in;
and click Send Enrollment email to notify the user of their enrollment.
Click Enroll.
The new user appears in the org unit’s classlist.

title: January 2024/20.24.1 Release Highlights Video

captions.text: This video is a selection of the new and updatedfeatures we're excited to share with you from
the January 2024 Release.
The full list of features can be found inthe January 2024 Version 20.24.1 Release Notes,
which you can find on Brightspace Community.
This month we’re highlighting the followingfeatures:
Export achievements as digital credentialsin Awards.
In Brightspace Editor, Insert Stuff now usesthe new file picker when uploading from a
users' computer.
Brightspace Data Sets improvements for Januaryin Data Hub.
With SIS Course Merge, the course merge forusers associated with multiple Source Systems
is consolidated.
And finally, a summary of the all the otherfeatures this month.
Let’s take a closer look at this month’sfeatures!
Learners can now export their awards in astandards-compliant format using the new Export
Digital Credential option.
This allows the download of certificates orbadges as an industry-standard Open Badges
2.0 compliant Badge.
Note that some third-party applications stripmeta-data from images, causing baked badges
to be non-compliant with Open Badges 2.0.
Previously, awards could only be exportedas a public URL or through the LinkedIn and
Badgr integrations.
Navigate to My Awards and select the desiredaward.
Click Share.
Click Export Digital Credential.
In the new window, enter and confirm youremail and then click Export.
The Awards feature implements the followingPIE Item:
D6128 (Awards: Incorporate Open Badge Standards)Thank you to Eric Floyd and all those who
put forward this PIE suggestion to implementthis feature!
The Awards feature is available to all clients.
To enable, set the configuration variabled2l.Tools.Awards.DigitalCredentialSharingEnabled
to ON at the Org level.
This feature not dependent on any existingpermissions.
This release updates the Insert Stuff > MyComputer file picker with the version currently
used in the Insert Image workflow, which allowsdrag and drop file uploads from the user's
computer.
Previously, the Insert Stuff > My Computerfile picker used an older file picker that
did not support drag and drop of files.
The Brightspace Editor feature implementsthe following PIE Item:
D10875 (Drag and Drop Option for Files inInsert Stuff)
Thank you to Nicole Schrock and all thosewho put forward this PIE suggestion to implement
this feature!
The Brightspace Editor feature is availableto all clients and is automatically enabled.
It does not rely on any new configurationvariables or permissions.
As of this release, the following BrightspaceData Sets (BDS) are no longer available:
Chat Objects and Chat Session Log.
Additionally, the following changes to existingBDS are available in this release:
Course Awards has the following new columns:Credits, LastModified, Version, and IsAssociated;
Outcomes Assessed Checkpoints has the followingnew column: HasMetAchievementThreshold.
The Data Hub feature is available to all BrightspaceCore Clients.
To enable, ensure the Can Access BrightspaceData Sets permission is granted to administrators
at the org level, and that the d2l.Tools.BrightspaceDataSets.Versionconfiguration variable is set to either version
New and changed data sets appear the firsttime the data set runs after the version update.
This update to SIS Course Merge functionalitysimplifies the process for users associated
with multiple Source Systems by consolidatingcourse management, enabling users to efficiently
conduct course merges within the same SIS.
Additionally, this release includes streamlinederror handling for more intuitive system feedback,
user interface refinements for easier navigation,and backend optimizations to increase reliability
and efficiency.
Previously, SIS Course Merge did not supportusers affiliated with multiple Source Systems
in merging courses.
The SIS Course Merge feature is availableto all clients and is automatically enabled.
It does not rely on any new configurationvariables or permissions.
Finally, let’s take a quick look at theother features for this month’s release.
Improved tooltip for unsaved changes to evaluationsin Assignments and Discussions.
Brightspace Virtual Assistance features anenhanced user interface and experience.
End of Life for Chat tool.
Improvements to Assignments and Grades Service(AGS) error handling in External Learning
Tools.
Easily differentiate outcomes statements usingshort codes in Outcomes Management.
And lastly, in Quizzes, written response questionsremain as pending evaluation until being manually
graded.
We hope you enjoyed this month’s releasehighlights.
As before, you can get the full details ofthis month’s changes in the January 2024
/ Version 20.24.1 Release Notes on BrightspaceCommunity.
See you next month!

title: December 2023/20.23.12 Release Highlights Video

captions.text: This video is a selection of the new and updatedfeatures we're excited to share with you from
the December 2023 Release.
The full list of features can be found inthe December 2023 Version 20.23.12 Release
Notes, which you can find on Brightspace Community.
This month we’re highlighting the followingfeatures:
View quiz start and quiz end dates as separateevents in Calendar.
Brightspace Data Sets Major Version 9 comingto Data Hub.
The New Discussion Topic Editing Experienceuniversally enabled in the Discussions Tool.
In Rubrics, the Grades tool is using ConsistentEvaluation interface for assessments.
Audit Log improvements for SIS Course Merge.
And finally, a summary of the all the otherfeatures this month.
Let’s take a closer look at this month’sfeatures!
When an instructor adds both a Start Dateand End Date in Quizzes and then selects Add
Availability Dates to Calendar, both datesare displayed in the Calendar tool as separate
events.
Previously, only one event was displayed,showing when the availability of that quiz
ended.
Navigate to your quiz and expand the AvailabilityDates & Conditions accordion.
Set a Start and End Date and Time.
Check Add availability dates to Calendar.
Then click Save and Close.
Navigate to Calendar.
In the Calendar, you will see entries forboth the Start Date and End Date for your
quiz.
Click on the Calendar entry to see more detailedinformation about
the quiz.
The Calendar feature implements the followingPIE Items:
D10060 (Consistency among Calendar Events(Start, Due, End Dates) for Quizzes and Assignments)
D7273 and D9956 (Add quiz start dates to calendarwidget); and
D5688 (Post Assignment and Discussion EndDates in the Calendar and Upcoming Events)
Thank you to all those who put forward thesePIE suggestions to implement this feature!
The Calendar feature is available to all clientsand is automatically enabled.
It is not dependent on any new permissionsor configuration variables.
Brightspace Data Sets (BDS) Major Version9 is now available.
Version 8 will be accessible until March 2024to give users four months to accommodate the
changes before migrating.
All clients will be automatically migratedto BDS Version 9 in April 2024.
The upgrade to Major Version 9 includes disruptivechanges to existing Brightspace Data Sets.
A full list of changes is in the Data Hub– Brightspace Data Sets improvements for
December | Updated release note in BrightspaceCommunity.
This Data Hub feature is available to allBrightspace Core clients.
To enable, ensure that the Can Access BrightspaceData Sets permission is granted to administrators
at the org level and that the d2l.Tools.BrightspaceDataSets.Versionconfiguration variable is set to version 9.0.
New and changed data sets appear the firsttime the data set runs after the version update.
For more information as to why these changesare happening, refer to Motivations behind
the changes in Data Hub Brightspace Data Set(BDS) Major Version 9 on Brightspace Community.
With this release, the New Discussion TopicEditing Experience, which was introduced in
the December 2022/Version 20.22.12 release,has completed the adoption program and is
now the only editing experience for all customers.
The New Discussion Topic Editing Experienceis set to on as the default with no option
to opt out, and the Legacy Discussion TopicEditing Experience is no longer available
after this release.
The d2l.Tools.Discuss.CreateExperienceOptIn(OrgUnit) configuration variable is deprecated
and is no longer available to site administrators.
This Discussions feature is available to allclients and is automatically enabled.
It is not dependent on any new permissionsor configuration variables.
When an evaluator assesses an assignment ordiscussion in the Grades tool, the rubric
now uses the Consistent Evaluation interface,even if there is no work submitted for evaluation.
This is consistent with the assessment experiencefor assignments or discussions in other areas
of Brightspace.
Previously, evaluations for these types ofactivities used a pop-out Rubric grid when
launching from the Grades tool.
When users click the drop-down menu on thecolumn header to enter grades, the rows with
un-submitted work now use the Consistent Evaluationexperience instead of the previous Rubric
pop-out.
Navigate to Grades and click the arrow besidethe desired assignment.
Then click Edit Grades.
You can access the Assessment even if thelearner has not submitted work.
Click the arrow to expand the Rubric.
You can view details about each level of therubric by moving your cursor over the slider.
Click the desired level to assign that score.
Once you’re finished, Click Publish.
This Rubrics feature is available to all clientsand is automatically enabled.
It is not dependent on any new permissionsor configuration variables.
This feature has the following accessibilityimprovements:
WCAG 2.1 Success criterion: 3.2.4 – ConsistentIdentification.
The SIS Course Merge Audit Log enhances administrators'tracking and understanding of course merge
activities with detailed merge and unmergelogs, user information, action timestamps,
advanced search options, and expandable logentries for in-depth information.
Previously, this functionality was handledby the Section Association tool, which did
not include an audit log.
The SIS Course Merge feature is availableto all clients and is automatically enabled.
Users must have the Can access the audit logfor all/my Courses permission granted to their
role to view the Audit Log tab within theSIS Course Merge tool.
Finally, let’s take a quick look at theother features for this month’s release.
Announcements now allows you to copy announcementsto other courses in a published state.
Interface improvements for annotations inAssignments.
Feedback field limitations for evaluationexperiences for both Assignments and Discussions.
Brightspace now features a branded footeron all main pages.
With Course Import, Homepage and NavigationBar NAME values retained for comparison within
parent orgunits.
Brightspace Data Sets improvements for Decemberin Data Hub.
In Discussions, Administrators can chooseforum workflow in the New Discussion Creation
Experience.
Associate Competencies to LTI and SCORM contentusing Create and Edit pages in Lessons.
Enforce Two Factor Authentication in Brightspacewith Local Authentication Security.
Manager Dashboard and Learning Groups nowdisplays unique identifiers and profile pictures.
Quizzes now better identifies bonus quiz questions.
And lastly, End of Life for the Homepage WidgetExpansion Pack.
We hope you enjoyed this month’s releasehighlights.
As before, you can get the full details ofthis month’s changes in the December 2023
/ Version 20.23.12 Release Notes on BrightspaceCommunity.
See you next month!

title: Part 2 | Import Data into Excel | Leveraging User Attributes in Brightspace Data Set Reporting

captions.text: To load this data into Excel, there's a few ways of doing that. One: You could just open all of these CSV's as tabs in a workbook, and that works if you've got small amounts of data.
If you've got large amounts and you're doing lookups, you can quickly run out of memory and Excel will grind to a halt. So there's a better way of doing that, and that's using Power Query.
So we will load these first two files because they're just single one-off data files. Go into Excel > Data > Get data > From Text/CSV, and we're gonna pull in... Let's pull in the Values first.
And the way I like to do it is "Load To..."
and Only Create Connection. This way. We're not creating a data tab, we're just connecting to a CSV file externally.
We're going to repeat that for the Definitions
Load To...
and we're only Creating Connection.

And these now can be combined to create a single file of attributes, because the Attribute Name is in the Definitions area, and the rest of the Ids and stuff (and values, of course) are in the Values file.

There's a couple ways of bringing in the User's data. Because we've got a bunch of files, 7 different files that we need to combine, we can either load them in from a folder, or load them in the same way we did these 2 files, and then connect them manually.

You would only do the latter if you didn't trust your data, or if there were errors that you are likely going to have to address. If you trust the data is clean and have some experience with this, then I like to go in,
Get Data > From File, go down to From Folder, and we're going to choose the Users folder. That brings up this menu, and we're going to choose Combine and Load To...

That's going to show us some data, and we can just look at that to make sure that everything looks good, that we've got the right kind of delimiters, and character set, and right kind of properties...
And then just click Ok...
and again choose Only Create Connection.
This creates a bunch more stuff which, if you trust your data, you don't need to fiddle with. To deal with the data that you've now read in, you can double click on any one of these connections,
and that opens up the Power Query window.
When we look at the User's data, which is just going to be this stuff here at the bottom,

we've got the Source file name, and then all of the rows from that file. And if we scroll all the way to the bottom, we're gonna see the Users_1, Users_2, which are going to be duplicate rows with new updated information.
To show that the differentials have brought in new data (that's updated duplicate rows) sort by... I like to do descending UserId, then scroll over to Version number,

click that, and also sort by descending Id. Notice the little #2 here shows that this is the second order sort. Now back over here we can see duplicated names, and the first in the list is from one of the differentials that was downloaded.

Now I 'want' to tell you that you could just Remove Duplicates right here. The problem is that doesn't just keep the first one that is found. In fact, it seems to keep whichever was loaded first. And, since that's not going to be something you can rely on, we need to handle this a little differently.
So we have this query, we need to create a new one so that we can fiddle with it, and that is going to be a Duplicate of the existing one.
Now this one, we're going to call "Max Version".
And in this table we are going to Transform > Group By...
We're going to start with the UserId and the new Version column is going to be the maximum value of the existing Version column.
So that now creates for each UserId a Version number. We can now merge this with the original
based on the matching UserId, and Version number, as a Left-Outer Join.
then expand.
and we can get rid of the Source Name column, UserId, and the Version from the new file, because we already have those.
And uncheck this option to "Use the original column name as a prefix" that'll keep it a little cleaner.
So the resulting data has Version in the wrong place. But it's now one row per user.
To make this look more original, I can just move the Version column all the way over to the right - It was the third last column in the file.

And now we want to save this query, and that's done through Close and Load. But if we don't choose the option to Create Connection Only, it's going to create this as a data tab in Excel, which we don't want just yet.
So we choose Close and Load To...
Create Connection Only.

title: Using the Brightspace (HTML) Editor | Instructor

captions.text: This video demonstrates how to use the Brightspace, or HTML, Editor.
Use Brightspace Editor anywhere where you want to create course content.
Format options allow you to set different text styles, like headings and code.
You can also bold, italicize, or underline text.
And you can use the color picker to select a color for your text.
Change the text alignment or make lists and indents for your content.
Insert Stuff opens a dialog where you can add files, video links, embed code, and a variety of other content.
Insert Quicklink lets you insert a link to a course activity or external content.
Add images to your content by clicking Insert Image.
Or add tables, dividers, equations, and more with Other Insert Options.
While editing, you can change how you view your content.
Click Fullscreen to work on your content in a larger space.
Click Source Code if you want to see and edit the HTML for your content.
Before publishing your content, click the Accessibility Checker to ensure your content is accessible for all your learners.
Click Preview to view your content before publishing it.

title: Create a Discussion Topic and Forum | Instructor

captions.text: This video demonstrates how to create a discussion topic and forum.

Encourage your learners to share thoughts on course material with peers by setting up forums and topics for learners to ask questions, discuss course content and assignments, and work together in assigned groups and sections.
Note that you must create a discussion forum first, which will contain associated discussion topics.
Discussion forums organize course discussion topics into categories such as weekly discussions, open discussions, and group discussions.
In a Content module, click Create New > Discussion.
First, create the forum by clicking Change Forum.
In the dialog, select Create a forum and enter a Forum Title.
Click Apply Changes.
Enter a Topic Title and Grade Out Of.
Click Standards if you wish to select and apply course standards to your discussion topic.
After, enter a Description to explain what you expect of learners’ responses.
Click the Availability & Conditions accordion to set a Start Date and End Date and choose the visibility of your discussion topic for both the start and end dates.
You can also add Release Conditions and Manage Restrictions.
Click the Post & Completion accordion to set how learner’s participation is displayed and to choose to set the topic as moderated.
Click the Evaluation & Feedback accordion to add a rubric and allow evaluations and ratings of posts.
Change the topic from Hidden to Visible and click Save and Close.
You have created a new forum and discussion topic.

title: Creating Timelines with Creator+ | Instructor

captions.text: This video demonstrates how to create and use the Creator+ Timeline element.
Use timelines to show a series of events, a workflow, a thought or creation process, or even a dialogue between two people.
In Content, click Create New and then click HTML Document.
Click the Other Insert Options menu and click Insert Element. Click Timeline.
In the Format Options section, select either Left-aligned or Alternating content.
Left-aligned content appears only on the left side of the timeline while alternating content appears in an alternating sequence on the left and right sides of the timeline.
Enter a title for your first timeline panel.
Then create content for the panel in the textbox below.
Repeat these steps until you’ve filled out each panel of your timeline.
Click Preview to review your timeline.
Then click Insert.
Your timeline appears in the Page Content textbox.
Add any additional content to your file, make the content Visible, and click Save and Close.
Your timeline is now available in your content topic.

title: Part 4  | Creating a Report | Leveraging User Attributes in Brightspace Data Set Reporting

captions.text: Now I can make a pretty simple and straightforward report using this data
by going to Insert > Pivot Table, and I'm going to create a pivot table on a new worksheet. For that we want... Let's use the Region (which is one of the attributes),
And then the UserId (we're going to need this to link data from other tables), and here in the pivot table I can filter out any empty, blank values.
So this just gives us UserIds from these various regions based on the attribute values. And then by adding in a few XLOOKUPS... let's do Username.
And I can pull in some additional data. Now, if I wanted to use a single XLSX file for my output, let's take this Final Grades data and move it into the file.
So now I've got something I can look up here within the same file.
And now look up Usernames and Grade Values.
And that gives us a very simple report of Users and Grades by Region. Another way to do it: Go back to the source here, we're going to say Insert > Pivot Table onto a new worksheet.
Here, we're going to drag all of the attribute values into the Filters area and look the users up once again based on the UserId.
And now I've got a report that I can filter by Department or by Region or Location.

title: Part 3 | Pivoting Data | Leveraging User Attributes in Brightspace Data Set Reporting

captions.text: Now we can start playing with the Attributes. Looking at the Attribute Values, we see UserIds and then a bunch of other properties about it. What we really want here is the Value column
and the rest of this stuff we don't necessarily need for the purposes of our report. So let's merge this with Definitions, because what we want from here is the Name.
So click on Attribute Values. We're going to Merge Queries
with Attribute Definitions
based on the AttributeId. Left-Outer is fine, because we want to keep all of the rows that appear in this table.
Then we expand the table

and we can just unselect everything and keep only the Name value. Now we want to reduce this to as few columns as possible. It isn't necessary, but it'll be a little easier to read the file while we perform the next step. So I'm just going to click on each of these columns that I want to delete.
You may want to filter out deleted columns - It's beyond the scope of this demonstration.
Now we've got the Name, the Value, and the UserId. Now with the name column highlighted, I'm going to click, Transform >
Pivot Column, and we're going to pivot based on the Value.

Make sure to open up advanced options, just in case it looked at numeric values and tried to aggregate. That's a thing that Excel really likes to do. We say, "Don't aggregate". I want to see the actual values. So instead of getting a count of values, we're gonna get either null or whatever value actually came in for Employee Id, Manager, Team, Location, all of the various Attribute Names.
We can now create our final data table using "Merge Queries as New".
We want Max Version, which is actually our Users table using the highest Version number (all the duplicates were removed). And we're going to mix that with our new User Attribute Values

which is the pivoted version. It's going to be based on the UserId and a Left-Outer join is what we want because we want all of the users, whether or not they actually have any attribute values attached to them.
Once this table is merged we have to expand it.
And we can uncheck UserId because we already have that value. And that now gives us all of these additional attributes as new columns.
I left the option to have this on as a prefix, because in some cases an attribute value might cause confusion as a column header if it looks the same as one of the other headers in the Users data.
Once we're done, let's give this a new name and call it Users with Attributes.

And if you wanted this just to exist as a query in the Power Query Editor, you could Close and Load To and choose the option to Only Create Connection. We actually want this data in Excel so just Close and Load, and that creates our new query "Users with Attributes" and the corresponding data tab.

title: Part 1 | Download & Unzip | Leveraging User Attributes in Brightspace Data Set Reporting

captions.text: The first thing we need to create an effective Users file, and integrate that with Attributes data, is to download the data from Data Hub. And we need the Users Data Sets.
So this here is the Full Data Set. We'll download that. And we're also gonna need to download some differentials. You can tell by the size of these files that there is data here.
So I like to download the last six ones, particularly if it's been a while since the full data set has been run.

You're also going to need the Attribute Values. I can tell none of these files have data in them. So no changes have happened here recently. And if you want to use the actual names of your Attributes, that is found in the User Attribute Definitions.
The downloaded files all need to be unzipped and you have to be careful that you're not overwriting one file with another. So here's how I do that. I unzip this file to its own folder.
Then I take all of the differentials and unzip them into the same folder, and take advantage of this option to Auto Rename the files. Now these can all be deleted.
And then we've got the Users files all in one place that I can bring into Excel. I'm also going to have to unzip these two, and if there were differentials I would do the same trick with them.
But for the moment we can get away with just unzipping them here.

title: Customize the Quiz Results Display | Instructor

captions.text: This video demonstrates how to customize the quiz results display for learners’ quiz submissions.
Creating a custom submission view provides learners with additional insight into their quiz attempt and the quiz attempts of their peers.
Click the Evaluation & Feedback accordion and click Customize Quiz Results Displays.
In the Primary View display section, click Edit View.
Enter a message in the Custom Message field.
In the Grade section, select or unselect the Display attempt grade for evaluated questions checkbox.
In the Questions drop-down menu, select an option for how you want quiz questions displayed after a learner submits their quiz.
For the Statistics section, select the desired checkboxes if you want the quiz grade average and the grade distribution stats displayed to learners.
Click Update.
If you want to add an additional view to the quiz, click the +Additional View button.
The customization options are the same except you can set a date and time when you want the additional view to appear.
When you’ve finished creating your additional view, click Create.
Click OK and then Save and Close.
Your custom quiz results display appears when learners submit their quiz.

title: Configure Local Two Factor Authentication | Administrator

captions.text: This video demonstrates how to configure local two factor authentication permissions for users in Brightspace.
Use two factor authentication to require two distinct forms of identification from users when they log in.
Two factor authentication improves security and neutralizes risks associated with compromised passwords.
Before beginning, ensure that the Local Authentication Security tool is enabled in Organization Tools.
This allows you to make changes to how users log in locally to Brightspace and whether they can configure two factor authentication.
By default, all users can log in locally.
In Roles and Permissions, click the role you want to configure from the Role List.
Filter to see the permissions for the Local Authentication Security tool. Then configure the following:
For the roles you want to be able to override Local Authentication Security for users, enable the Can Override Users Local Authentication Security Setting permission.
For the roles you no longer want to be able to perform local login, select the Disable Allowing Local Login permission.
For the roles you want to be able to configure two factor authentication for local login, enable the Make Two Factor Authentication Available permission.
For any users where these role permissions should be overridden, in the Users tool, search for the user and click their name.
From the User Info tab, navigate to the Local Authentication section.
Select the Override default role settings for this user setting.
Select whether the Local Brightspace Login Availability is Available to the user.
If available, the user can log in to Brightspace locally regardless of their role permissions.
Select whether Two Factor Authentication Availability is Not Available or Optional.
If Optional, the user can configure two factor authentication from their Account Settings.

title: Create Certificates | Instructor

captions.text: This video demonstrates how to create a certificate in Brightspace.
Certificates can be automatically issued based on release condition criteria or manually awarded to learners to recognize their efforts.
In the Awards tool, select the Course Awards tab. Click Add Award to Course and then click Create.
On the New Award page, enter a Name, Description, and Criteria for your new certificate.
From the Award Type drop-down list, select Certificate.
In the Availability field, select the appropriate check boxes to indicate how you want the award to be available to other award managers.
In the Expiry Field, choose the dates when you want the award to be available to learners.
In the Choose Award Image section, select an existing icon or upload a new one.
You can also launch the OpenBadges website to create your own award image.
In the Choose Certificate Template area, select an existing template or upload a new template.
After entering your Issuer Information, select the Use this award in  now check box to make your certificate available in your course.
Click Save and Close.
The award is added to your course awards list.
