Then select an existing or create a new departmentfor the template and course to be housed within.
For this example, click the department Dropdownmenu...
and select a department.
Then, using a naming convention consistentwith your organization to enter a folder path.
This will create the folder that houses contentrelated files added to a course offering.
When you are done editing the template, clickNext.
Now, add information about the new courseoffering.
Enter a name for your course offering.
This is the name that will display to users.
Then, enter a course offering code.
The course code ResDev01 indicates that thiscourse relates to resume development and this
will be the first time it is offered.
You can change your preferred locale fromthe Locale dropdown menu.
If you select Force Locale, the course offeringwill override user’s locale settings.
For this example, we will leave the defaultlocale selected.
In the start and end date sections you canspecify when a course will be available to
users.
Finally, specify a file path for course contentto be stored.
Use a course offering path that incorporatesthe appropriate department or template and
course offering.
When you are ready, click Next.
A summary of your course offering and templateinformation displays.
When you are satisfied with your selections,click Create.
Continue making changes to your course offeringor template from the Summary page.
When you are ready, click Done.
Your new course is now available.
Manually set up course offerings for yourorganization using Course Management.

title: Release Highlights - February 2019 (Version 10.8.10) - Administrator

captions.text: This video highlights some of the new andupdated features of Brightspace Learning Environment
Assignment Grader no longer supports EduDentity.Login is now completed using Brightspace credentials.
A new permission has been added to supportthe Evaluator role.
The Edit Evaluation Properties, Assignmentspermission must be set at the organization
and course offering levels for Evaluators.
All roles with the Add/Edit permission areautomatically assigned the Edit Evaluation
Properties permission.
Insights Portal has been improved to includea new embedded Adoption Dashboard, improvements
to user experience, and release of the AdoptionDashboard in Canada.
Administrators must have the new Can See AdoptionDashboard permission at all levels, and existing
Query Data Platform at the organization level.
The BaseContentAbsolutePath value is obsoletefor Bulk Course tools and has been removed.
You can now set org-level default settingsfor indicators in the Class Progress dashboard
and User Progress report.
This feature implements PIE item D2047.
The Class Progress, Modify Org Default ProgressIndicators permission must be assigned to users.
Select Class Progress and User Progress.
Note: The Modify Org Default Progress Indicators,Class Progress permission must be set at the
Organization level to access this feature.
Here you can select which indicators displayby default on the Class Progress dashboard
for your organization. By default, ContentCompletion, Objectives Completion, Login
History for the last 30 days, and ChecklistCompletion display.
To reset Class and User Progress for all courses,select the Reset all courses to use these
default settings checkbox.
Click an indicators context menu...
and select Replace.
Here you can select another indicator.
Assignment Data sets have been updated. Newcolumns have been added to the Assignment
data sets.
The Assignment Summary data set now includesSubmissionType (including the new On Paper
and Observed in Person values), and CompletionTypecolumns.
The Assignment Submissions data set now includesa CompletionDate column.
The d2l.Tools.BrightspaceDataSets.Versionconfiguration variable has been removed.
Users currently using Brightspace Data Sets version1 are automatically upgraded to version 2.
New columns have been added to data sets.AwardCredits has been added to Awards, and
GradeReleasedDate has been added to GradeResults.
The new Enrollments and Withdrawals Data Setsare now available. This data set provides
all enrollment actions from all time acrossyour organization.
The Org Units data set has been updated. Youare now able to override the Type column in
the Org Units data set for groups definedas Sections.
The Can Access Brightspace Data Sets permissionmust be set for administrators at the organization level.
Manager Dashboard and learning Groups hasbeen updated. In Learning Groups, when viewing
course assignments for individual learninggroup members on the User Details page, only
the specific courses assigned by the currentlearning group display.
Your instructors now have access to the e-raterGrammar checker. E-rater Grammar immediately
provides feedback to learners on assignmentsubmission.

title: Brightspace Capture™ - Add Chapters to a CaptureCast™ Presentation - Instructor

captions.text: Segment a presentation into chapters to enable viewers to navigate through the presentation easily.
This tutorial shows how to use the Producertool to add chapters to a published presentation.
To begin, click Admin. Note: the Admin page
is only available when you are logged in.Next, click Presentations.
Identify the presentation you want to modify. Click the context menu and select Open in Producer.
Now, enter a Chapter title and click the Add new item icon.
The time indicates the point in the presentation
where the chapter begins.Note: The chapter extends until the start
of the next chapter or the end of the presentation,whichever comes first.
Next, let's create an additional chapter.Enter another chapter title and click the
Add new item icon. To adjust the chapter's start time click and
drag the timeline marker along the timeline bar.
Then, click Save.Repeat this process until you have finished
segmenting the presentation into chapters.At any point you can go back and modify the
chapters you've created. To do so, selecta chapter from the list.
Edit the selected chapter's title or starttime.
Or, click delete to remove the chapter altogether.Click save when you are finished adding and
modifying chapters.Now, when viewing the presentation the event
timeline is segmented into chapters.Segment a presentation into chapters to enable
viewers to navigate through the presentationeasily.

title: Release Highlights - May 2020 v.20.20.5 - Administrator

captions.text: This video highlights some of the new and updated features of Brightspace Learning Environment 20.20.5.
The d2l.Tools.News.AuthorInformationDefault configuration variable has been changed to
d2l.Tools.News.DisplayAuthorInformation and the Can Manage Author Information and Settings
permission is now Change Display Author Information.
Welsh is now available in Brightspace Learning Environment.
Brightspace Pulse now supports multi-account login. For more information, review the release notes.
To improve load times, top level units and active lessons in the new content experience table of contents
are now expanded.
You can now bulk delete items from Calendar. This feature implements PIE items D432 and D1134.
Select the Calendar events you want to delete,
Click More Actions...
and select Delete.
This release adds the Org Unit Type ID column to the Org Units data set to support the initiative to expose all
updates and inserts in differentials. You must have the Can Access Brightspace Data Sets permission at the org
level, and the d2l.Tools.BrightspaceDataSets.Version configuration variable set to version 4 or 5.
Developers can now use the Brightspace Developer Platform API to enable the Is Discoverable
option on courses. This feature implements PIE item D5908.
You can now optionally configure enrollment logs to record Discover as the enrolled by type so Instructors
can view which users are self-enrolling in their courses using Disover. This feature implements PIE item D5669.
For more information review the release notes.
There have been updates to the email configuration variables that are editable by client administration roles.
For more information, review the release notes.
The default file name for exported courses now includes the org unit code of the course being exported.
This feature implements PIE item D6269.
Your Instructors can now select a checkbox to indicate they want the feedback provided on hidden rubrics to be
transferred back to general feedback.
Note: The d2l.Tools.Rubrics.CreateExperienceOptIn configuration variable must be set to On or On (opt-in).
This feature implements PIE item D5624.
Lessons has been updated to include new Add Existing and Create New options.
Landing pages in Manager Dashboard and Learning Groups now sort items consistently.
For more information review the release notes.
To improve load times top level units andactive lessons in the New Content Experience
Table of Contents are now expanded, and all other modules are collapsed.
You can now link multiple Brightspace Orgs in a multi-site arrangement.
Thanks for watching! We are always looking to hear from you about the kinds of videos you want to see.
Leave us a comment below, and as always - don't forget to subscribe!

title: Learning Environment - Making Use of the Equation Editor - Instructor

captions.text: Add graphical, MathML, and LaTeX equationsto your content using the Graphical Equation
Editor.This tutorial shows how to insert a mathematical
equation into the HTML Editor using the Graphicalequation editor in Brightspace Learning Environment.
The Graphical Equation Editor enables youto insert mathematical equations or draw chemical
bonds within the HTML Editor in most BrightspaceLearning Environment tools that have HTML
content creation capabilities, such as discussiontopics, custom instructions for assignment
folders, content topics, and more.To begin, from the HTML Editor where you want
to create an equation, click Show All Componentsto reveal the Graphical equation drop-down
menu, among other options.Click Graphical equation.
The editor provides the necessary elementsto construct equations quickly and easily.
Each tab in the editor tool bar opens a paletteof related mathematical symbols.
From the General tab, you can build equationsusing common mathematical elements, such as
fractions, roots, or operators, as well asformat the text.
From the Symbols tab, you can add standardand less common operators, such as pi, almost
equal to, or the greater than sign, to yourequation.
From the Arrows tab, you can add arrows, ellipses,and dashes to your equation.
From the Greek, letters and numbers tab youcan add symbols such as those for epsilon,
real numbers, or elements from the periodictable to your equation.
From the Matrices and elementary tab, youcan setup equations with multiple rows and
columns.From the Scripts and layout tab, you can setup
equations with fractions, roots, or a superor sub script.
From the Decorations tab, you can add accents,or strikethroughs to your equation.
From the Big operators tab, you can find sumor product operators in a large font, or,
you can enter your own.From the Calculus tab, you can add integrals,
differentials, limits, and other related functionsto your equation.
For this example, we will create the equationfor converting Fahrenheit degrees to Celsius
degrees.To begin, let T stand for temperature.
From the General tab, click Subscript.Then, enter a value for the subscript to represent
Fahrenheit degrees.Enter an equals sign.
Then, navigate to the Scripts and layout taband click Big fraction.
Then, enter values nine fifths for the fraction.Next, we will enter a value representing the
degrees in Celsius.Navigate to the Symbols tab.
Click the Plus sign and add 32.When you are ready, click Insert to include
the equation in your content.A preview appears inline in the HTML editor.
The way you access the HTML and Graphicalequation editors is slightly different for
quizzes.From Quizzes, when you click a field to which
formatting can be applied. The HTML Editorappears.
From the HTML editor, you can select the Graphicalequation editor and select the type of equation
you want to create.For this example, create a LaTeX equation.
Enter a LaTeX command into the equation field.A preview of the equation appears.
When you are ready, click Insert.A preview of the equation appears as you continue
to create or edit the question.Add graphical, MathML, and LaTeX equations
to your content using the Graphical EquationEditor.

title: Competencies - Create a Learning Objective - Instructor

captions.text: Incorporate learning objectives into competencystructures to help track the knowledge, skills,
and abilities learners acquire as they participatein courses.
This tutorial shows how to create a learningobjective.
To begin, click New......and select Learning Objective.
Enter a name.
It is a good practice to use a name the clearlyidentifies the learning objective.
Add a description, if desired.
You can also add an additional identifierif, for example, a professional or academic
standard corresponds to the learning objective.
If you wish to restrict which activity typescan be associated with the learning objective,
select Yes in the Enforced Assessment Methodsection and then select the check boxes beside
the activity types you want to allow.
Leave No selected to avoid making any restrictions.
Note that once your learning objective issaved these settings cannot be altered.
Now determine if the learning objective isready for evaluation.
When No is selected learners cannot completethe learning objective.
Select to Yes to make completion possible.
When you are done click Save.
The learning objective has been created andis now ready to be incorporated into competency
structures.
Incorporate learning objectives into competencystructures to help track the knowledge, skills,
and abilities learners acquire as they participatein courses.

title: Release Highlights - September 2018 (Version 10.8.5) - Administrator

captions.text: This video highlights some of the new and updated features of Brightspace Learning Environment 10.8.5.
Parents can now see Discussion details such as discussion
name and instructions. If an end date or gradeitem is assigned to a discussion, it will
display in the Upcoming Work and Recent Gradeswidgets, respectively.
When viewing the Upcoming Work widget parentscan now click a Discussion topic...
to view instructions, grades if applicable,and availability.
Clients no longer have access to the IIS LogsReport.
Evidence in Brightspace Portfolio can nowbe aligned to course outcomes to better communicate
how the evidence supports learning.Users can now print and download an uploaded
syllabus from Course Overview.This feature implements PIE item D3679.
Note: This feature will display differentlybased on the setting of the d2l.System.Services.DocumentConversion.IsEnabled
configuration variable. For more details,review the release notes.
New Print and Download buttons appear in CourseOverview for users with the “Download Content
Topics” content permission enabled.Note: When viewing a PDF file only Download
is visible to users.A variety of new columns are available in
Brightspace Data Sets.A new advanced data set, Impersonated Session
History, indicates sessions that were impersonatedby an administrator or D2L Support.
User Logins data set now correctly reportsimpersonated logins.
You, and your instructors, can now associateexisting discussion topics with new, or existing,
groups or sections.When creating or editing a group or section,
in Create Workspaces, click Set up discussionareas.
Select Create new topic to create a new discussiontopic, or select the new Attach to existing
topic option to create group or section restrictedthreads in an existing discussion topic.
Note: You can only create group restrictedthreads for empty topics without existing
posts or group restrictions.Users with the Manage Grades permission can
now see the exact date and time a learner’sgrade is released or unreleased in the Grade
Event Log. Note: Historical data is not availablefor grades that were released or unreleased
prior to this feature.Usernames and Ord Defined Ids can now be displayed
in Groups and Sections to differentiate betweenduplicate learner names.
This feature implements PIE items D2801 andD777.
Click Settings...to choose a differentiator or Username or
Org Defined ID.Note: This feature requires the View User’s
Org Defined IDs Users permission, and theSee Usernames User Information Privacy permissions
to be enabled.Users can now directly link directly to content
modules, submodules and the course overviewdirectly from the HTML Editor. Previously,
only a link to the Content tool was availablein the HTML Editor.
This feature implements PIE items D545, D2033and D1731.
When using the HTML Editor, click Insert Quicklink.Select Content...
and navigate to the desired topic.Chemistry equations and handwriting, using
a stylus or finger for input, are now availablein the HTML Editor.
This feature implements PIE item D3383.Anywhere the HTML Editor is available, click
the Graphical Equation dropdown menu.and select the new Chemistry Equation
to use chemical symbols to createan equation, or click Go to handwritten mode...
and manually write out your equation.Note: this feature does not enable hand-drawn
graphs.
When you are ready, click Insert.
Now, the TII Submission ID is displayed inthe Submission History page when a learner
makes a submission to a Turnitin enabled submissionfolder.
Awards, and their release conditions, cannow be copied between courses allowing for
awards to be reused between courses and sections.This feature implements PIE items D2707 and
D4128.In Lessons, learning objects can now be published
to and from Brightspace Learning Object Repository.When adding content to Lessons, instructors
can now add from the Learning Object Repository,and...
new content can be published to LOR.The new Assigned Learning microservice is
used by Manager Dashboard and Learning Groupsto store due dates.
You can now set course due dates in ManagerDashboard when assigning courses to Learning
Groups.The due date appears in the Course and User
Details pages to easily view and track courseprogress. Due dates apply to all members of
a learning group.A new released final grade score release condition
type is available everywhere a user can createand attach release conditions.
This feature implements PIE items D699, D4295,and D4329.
When creating a new release condition, thereis now a Released final grade score condition
type, select it...and navigate to Condition Details....
to specify whether the content will releasewith the final grade, or only if the learner
earns a specific score on their final grade.The ability to schedule Wiggio virtual meetings
is no longer available to clients.Want to see the full workflow for creating
group/section threads in discussions? Checkout the link in the video!

title: Intelligent Agents - Delete and Restore Intelligent Agents - Instructor

captions.text: Use intelligent agents to monitor login activity, course activity, and release conditions in your course.
This tutorial shows how to delete and restorean intelligent agent.
To begin, from Intelligent Agents, selectthe intelligent agent you are deleting.
Then, click Delete.
A confirmation displays, click Delete to continue.
Your intelligent agent no longer displays.
To restore a deleted agent, click More Actions.and select Restore.
All deleted agents associated with your coursewill display.
Click restore for the agent you want to re-addto your course.
Restored agents no longer display in the RestoreAgents page.
Click Intelligent Agents in the breadcrumbtrail to view the agents associated with your
course.
The restored agent displays.
Use intelligent agents to monitor login activity,course activity, and release conditions in
your course.

title: Discussion - Moderate Discussions - Instructor

captions.text: Approve and remove responses by moderatinga discussion.
This tutorial will show you how to moderatea discussion.
To begin, from Discussions, navigate to thediscussion you want to moderate.
When a topic requires moderation, the moderationicon displays. These posts are only visible
to users with permission to approve them.The number of posts that require approval
display.Click View Unapproved Posts to only show threads
containing unapproved posts.
Click the status menu....
... to filter posts by Unread, Flagged, Drafts,or Unapproved.
For this example, view Unapproved.
Click View unapproved replies...
... and navigate to the unapproved post.
Review the learner’s post.For this example, we will approve the post.
Click Approve Post.
A confirmation appears.Note: By confirming a post as approved, all
parent posts that have not been approved willalso be approved with this action.
When you are ready, click Yes.
Clear the Status Filter to view all posts.
To unapprove a message, click the contextmenu of the post you want to edit...
...and select Unapprove Post.From the context menu, you can also View Post
History to see all edited versions of themessage, who edited it and when it was approved.
Approve and remove inappropriate responsesby moderating a discussion.

title: Question Library & Import/Export/Copy Components - Add Questions from Other Courses - Instructor

captions.text: Reuse and share quiz questions between courses by copying questions from one Question Library
to another. This tutorial shows how to add questions from one course to another.
Copying questions from one course Question
Library to another is done using Import/Export/CopyComponents. To begin, navigate to Import/Export/Copy
Components.From Copy Components from another Org Unit,
click Search for offeringIn the Search For field enter search details,
for this example we will use part of the coursecode.
click Search...and select the course to copy questions from.
Then, click Add Selected.Next, click Select Components.
Navigate to...and select Question Library.
You can specify which questions to copy byselecting Select individual items to copy,
or as in this example, copy all items. Whenyou are ready, click Continue.
Lastly, click Finish.Your copy begins. You can monitor its progress
with the progress bar.When the copy is completed a pop-up notification
displays. Now, when you navigate to QuestionLibrary...
the newly copied questions display.Reuse and share quiz questions between courses
by copying questions from one Question Libraryto another.

title: Assignments - Grade Assignment Submissions Offline - Instructor

captions.text: Grade assignments offline so you have the flexibilityto evaluate and leave feedback for learners
on your own time.This tutorial shows how to download and grade
learners’ submissions offline before providingonline feedback.
From Assignments…
click the assignment that you want to grade.
Then, click Submissions.
Navigate to the submitted files…
…and select all of them.
Click Download to generate a ZIP file thatcontains all of the submissions.
Then, click the file to download it to yourdevice.
Click Close.
Unzip the file to access the submission files.
Learners can submit files in a variety offormats.
Inform your learners of your preferred submissionfile format.
This helps ensure you can grade files usingyour preferred software.
Grade the submission files…
…and save your changes to the file.
When you are ready to provide your learnerswith the evaluation, return to the Assignment
in Assignments.Note: You can also bulk upload the graded
submissions back to the appropriate assignmentso they appear as attachments to each learner’s
submission evaluation.Upload the graded submissions (with the file
names exactly the same as when downloaded),and index file in a ZIP file to ensure the
automatic distribution process runs smoothly.
For this example, click a learner’s submission to provide feedback.
In the Evaluation section, provide the learnerwith the score they achieved on the assignment.
Then, navigate to Feedback.
Click Add a File to attach your graded submissionfile.
Click My Computer.
Upload your file by clicking Upload, or draggingand dropping the file onto the upload target.
To confirm the upload, click Add.
Click Save Draft to save feedback and continuegrading submissions or Publish to release
your feedback to the learner.When you publish feedback, if the folder is
associated with a grade item, the grade willalso be pushed to the grade book.
Note: As you grade each submission, you canclick Previous Student or Next Student to
browse to other submissions.
Grade assignments offline so you have flexibilityto evaluate and leave feedback for learners
on your own time.

title: Question Library - Create a Matching Question - Instructor

captions.text: Be ready to assess learners’ recognitionand comprehension of specific relationships
by creating and storing matching questionsin Question Library.
This tutorial shows how to create a matchingquestion in Question Library.
To begin, from the Quizzes tool, click QuestionLibrary.
Click New and select Matching Question.
Enter a title for your question, if desired.
The title displays in the question list inQuestion Library.
Then, enter the number of points you wantthe question to be worth.
Enter your problem in the Question Text field.
Select the grading method for the question.
In each Value field, enter a choice.
To add additional values for the question,enter the number of choices you want to add
to the question, and click Add Choice.
In the Matches area, if necessary, add additionalmatches so the number of possible values equals
the number of possible matches.
For example, in this question there are 10values with 10 matches.
In each Value field, enter a choice.
From the drop-down list for each matchingvalue, select the corresponding Correct Choice.
View how the question will display by clickingPreview
You can preview how the question appears tolearners, how it appears when grading, and
any comments or hints.
Click Done when you are ready to exit thepreview.
When you are satisfied with your question,click Save.
Your question is saved in Question Library.
Be ready to assess learners’ recognitionof information and comprehension of specific
relationships by creating and storing matchingquestions in Question Library.

title: Add External Content to a Course | Instructor

captions.text: This is part two of a four-part video series that will walk you
through various course setup management features.
To add external files from your computer using drag-and-drop,
navigate to the course level navbar and select Content to access the Content tool.
In the left-hand table of contents, select the module you would like to add the files to,

to add external files directly to your module using your keyboard or the user interface, select

files from your computer;course offering files;

title: Intelligent Agents - View and Edit the Schedule of an Intelligent Agent - Instructor

captions.text: Optimize when intelligent agent notifications are sent by editing their schedule.
This tutorial shows how to view and edit the schedule of an intelligent agent.
To begin, from Intelligent Agents, click the context menu for the agent whose schedule you want to edit.
And select Edit.
Navigate to Scheduling.
The Scheduling section outlines the agent’s frequency, as well as the duration of the agent’s recurrence.
Click Update Schedule.
For this example, we will leave the agent running every day...
but update the scheduled start date.
Click the Start Date, and update it to reflect your desired change.
When you are ready, click Update.
When you are satisfied with your changes, click Save and Close.
To view the time intelligent agents are scheduled to run, click Settings.
And view the Scheduled Agents Run Time section.
Optimize when intelligent agent notifications are sent by editing their schedule.

title: Concepts for Administrators - Enterprise Organization Structure - Administrator

captions.text: The organization or "org" structure is a hierarchicalstructure comprised of individual org units
that are arranged in parent-child relationships.This tutorial provides an example overview
of a basic org structure and its org unitswhile discussing how you can use this structure
to organize your company in D2L Learning Environment.This is an example of a basic org structure.
The organization, department, course template,and course offering org units are required.
All other org units are optional ways to definethe hierarchy.
We will discuss each org unit individually.Note: Semesters are customizable org units
that divide course offerings into time-basedcategories, such as a year’s quarter.
However, many companies choose not to usethis optional org unit.
First, we will discuss the organization orgunit, which is highlighted in orange.
The organization org unit – also known asthe “My Home” page in D2L Learning Environment
– is the highest level of the structureand represents your entire company.
At this level, you can define elements thatwill be common to all users throughout the
entire company, such as the default homepage.For this example, we look at the org structure
for the fictional company Hamilton Inc.Next, we'll look at custom org units.
You can tailor custom org units to createan additional level or levels of structure
between the organization and department orgunits.
These optional org units can be parallel orhierarchical to each other.
If you have multiple divisions, it can behelpful to divide your org structure by these
locations if they host a unique set of courseofferings.
For example, the Canadian and US divisionsare custom org units that comprise the overall
company.Departments are mandatory org units that divide
the org level or custom org units.Department org units organize courses and
learners within the overall hierarchy.You can define these org units however you’d
like.For example, a department org unit can represent
a subject or career level.In this example, the department org units
house the Human Resources and Finance departments.Next, we will discuss course templates.
Course templates add an extra level of structurebetween departments and course offerings.
They act as a container that collects relatedcourse offerings.
Note: Course templates and course offeringshave a parent-child relationship.
Course offerings must be the child of a coursetemplate.
For example, Hamilton Inc. subdivides theirHuman Resources department into onboarding
and health and safety categories.Course templates group together courses offerings
that fall within these categories.Next, we will discuss course offerings.
Course offerings are the courses in whichlearners are enrolled and where they access
their learning materials.In general, facilitators populate a course
offering.Learners access course offerings from the
organization homepage using the course selectoron the minibar.
In this example, Hamilton Inc. offers twospecialized Health and Safety courses, Fire
Safety and Workplace Hazards.You can further subdivide course offerings
into sections.Sections allow administrators or facilitators
to subdivide a course offering into multiplesections.
This is especially useful for dividing largeclass lists into more manageable units.
In this example, Fire Safety trainingis subdivided into two sections to indicate
their office location -- Kitchener or Waterloo.Groups provide an additional layer of structure
to the hierarchy.Groups divide a course offering for the purpose
of group work.You can create multiple categories for groups
and enroll learners into one or more groups.Note: Sections divide the classlist into distinct
chunks.Groups allow organized collaboration.
In this example, the class is divided intotwo collaborative groups for a project.
Finally, we will discuss semesters.Semesters are an optional org unit.
You can use semesters to divide course offeringsinto time-based categories.
You can choose not to implement semestersif your organization offers open-ended course
offerings that continue for unspecified amountsof time, with new users enrolling whenever
they like.Org structures are flexible in their composition.
You can tailor org units to best fit yourorganization's purpose.
This is an example of an out-of-the-box organizationstructure.
You can customize additional org units tostructure your company.
As a best practice, you should liaise withD2L Implementation Consultants to design and
create the ideal organization structure.

title: Quizzes - Take a Quiz - Learner

captions.text: Take evaluations - which could include a quiz,mid-term, or final exam - using Quizzes.
This tutorial shows how to take a quiz inBrightspace Learning Environment.
To begin, from the Quiz List page, navigateto the quiz you want to take...
Read the Quiz Details.
This gives you important information such as the quiz period,
due date, time allotted, and number of attempts.
Read the quiz instructions carefully.
The instructions contain important informationsuch as whether you can look back at pages
of the quiz you have already completed, orwhat happens if you don’t finish the quiz
in the allotted time.When you’re ready, click Start Quiz!
If your quiz is timed, the time limit andthe time remaining appear following the quiz
name.An outline, showing the number of questions
and page structure appear in the Questionssection.
For example, this quiz has 5 questions. Twoquestions on the first page, and three on
the second page.Quizzes can include a wide variety of types
of questions, such as multiple-choice, shortanswer, essay, or even mathematical questions.
Enter your response for each question.Answers auto save as you complete the quiz.
When you are ready click, Next Page.In some cases, your instructor may restrict
you from moving backwards in a quiz.If so, you will need to acknowledge that you
want to proceed with the quiz.Continue answering quiz questions.
When you are done answering all questions,click Submit Quiz.
A confirmation appears. Select Yes to continue.To submit your quiz, click Submit Quiz.
The submission summary displays.Your instructor may choose to make your results
available to you right away or at a laterdate.
If you make multiple attempts at a quiz, yourAttempt Score and Overall Grade may be different
to reflect the scoring method your instructorchooses.
For example, the Overall Grade can reflectthe average number of attempts or the
highest score achieved.
When you have finished reviewing the summary, click Done.
Take evaluations - which could include a quiz, mid-term, or final exam - using Quizzes.

title: Enrollments - Overview - Administrator

captions.text: Creating and enrolling users (administrators,instructors, learners, and other custom roles)
gives them access to your instance of BrightspaceLearning Environment.
This tutorial defines and discusses user enrollmentin Brightspace Learning Environment.
Enroll users in your Brightspace LearningEnvironment at any org unit to grant them
access to that unit, such as a course offering.You assign permissions to a user for a specific
org unit by enrolling them in that org unitas a specific role.
User enrollment at the org level is requiredto log in to your Brightspace Learning Environment.
When you create a user, they are enrolledat the org level.
As the administrator, you define users' enrollmentsand the associated roles, and permissions.
There are different options for enrollingusers and managing their Brightspace Learning
Environment access.You can manually or automatically enroll users
in an org unit and assign the appropriaterole and permissions. In some situations,
you can enable self registration so userscan enroll themselves in the system. Alternatively,
you can implement external Student InformationSystems or Human Resources applications to
manage user enrollment.
Creating and enrolling users (administrators,instructors, learners, and other custom roles)
gives them access to your instance of BrightspaceLearning Environment.

title: Quizzes - Create a Quiz Report - Instructor

captions.text: Use quiz reports to gather information onlearner performance.
This tutorial shows how to create a quiz report.
From Quizzes, click the quiz to which you want to add the report.
Click Reports Setup.
Click Add Report.
Enter a Report Name.
Next, select a report type.There are five types of quiz reports that
you can create: Question Statistics, QuestionDetails, Users Statistics, Attempt Details,
and User Attempts.
For this example, we will create a Question Statistics report.
Create a Question Statistics report to identify potentially problematic questions.
Create a Question Details report to assess the quality and characteristics of quizzes
and individual items - or questions - in a quiz.
Create a Users Statistics report to evaluate
how learners are performing in a quiz.
Create an Attempt Details report to measure the completion time for the quiz and individual questions.
Or, create a User Attempts report to identifywhich learners have tried the quiz.
Reports can be released immediately or ata predefined date and time.
For this example, we will define the releasedetails.
Using the calendar, select the date the reportwill be released.
Finally, select the audience for the report.For this example, we will release the report
to instructors.Click Save to finish setting up the report.
Click Save and Close to finalize the report.
Use quiz reports to gather information on learner performance.

title: Release Highlights - August 2017 (version 10.7.4) - Administrator

captions.text: This video highlights some of the new and updated features of Brightspace Learning Environment 10.7.4.
Instructors can now create assignment submissionfolders with an optional grade item, and post
them to Activity Feed as an assignment post.
From your course homepage, in the ActivityFeed widget, click Create a post.
Click the Assignment tab.
Enter a title, instructions, and a due date.
If you would like to add the assignment asa grade item, click Add to Grades.
Then, click Post.
The instructor view of assignment posts includeshow many learner submissions have been received.
Learners can submit their assignments directlyfrom the post and monitor the status of their
submission.Once a learner uploads a submission, the "Submit"
button changes color and displays either "Submitted"or "Graded", depending on its current status.
Or, they can comment on the post if they havequestions, or want to start a discussion.
Instructors can now set the visibility statefor draft content within assignment submission
folders in Content and Assignments.
From the Restrictions tab of a New SubmissionFolder, the availability defaults to Hidden
from users, which is the draft visibilitystate.
When instructors have set the visibility todraft, the hidden icon appears in the instructor
view of the assignment.Instructors can also click an assignment's
context menu and select Hide from Users tohide the assignment from learners.
These settings are automatically pulled fromthe Assignment Submission Folder and displayed
in Content.Additionally, the course export process now
includes the visibility state for the assignmentcontent, which comes from the Assignment folder.
Brightspace for Parents is releasing withlimited availability to clients in the US
and Canada.
Currently optimized for K-12 clients, Brightspacefor Parents uses the Holding Tank, OneRoster,
or IPSIS LIS 2.0 SIS integrations to createparent-child relationships in Brightspace
Learning Environment.This allows authorized parents and guardians
to view their child's class activity feed,portfolio items, and upcoming assignments,
from their own parent account.Check your organization’s policies regarding
data residency and consult with your legaladvisors to ensure that you have the appropriate
permissions to use this product. Then, contactyour D2L Account Manager to ask about using
Brightspace for Parents.
Brightspace Portfolio is releasing with limitedavailability to clients in the US and Canada.
It is not recommended that clients use bothBrightspace Portfolio and ePortfolio concurrently.
After Portfolio is turned on in Org Tools,the configuration variable is turned on, and
the appropriate endpoint is set, the followingpermissions are required.
Administrators or Instructors who intend toadd category tags must have the Can Add Portfolio
Tags permission at the Organization level.Instructors must have the Search for ,
View User Enrollments, and Can Access thePortfolio Instructor View permissions.
And learners must have the View Other Users’Profiles and Student Portfolio Access permissions.
If you intend to use Brightspace for Parentsto share evidence, it must be configured and
turned on in Brightspace Learning Environment
Instructors and learners can use BrightspacePortfolio in Brightspace Learning Environment
to manage the information they have addedto their portfolios.
Administrators and instructors can createcategories to tag evidence according to course
learning objectives or other collections.
There are new Brightspace Portfolio iOS andAndroid apps to help learners create a record
of their learning by guiding them to captureevidence and reflecting on it.
Learners can use the portfolio app on a classroomdevice to capture images of their best work
and record an audio reflection, which is thenmanaged by instructors in Brightspace Learning
Environment.You must load and set up the portfolio app
on the classroom device as well as set upthe Brightspace Portfolio tool in Brightspace
Learning Environment.
Icons reflecting the Daylight look and feelhave been reintroduced in Content.
This feature implements PIE item D3333.
Daylight icons reflecting different contentfile types are visible in the main Table of
Contents view, the Module Content view, andthe Table of Contents fly-out menu when viewing
a topic or activity. Before the icons will display, the d2l.system.BrightspaceDaylightExperience
configuration variable must be turned on.
You can now turn on a new navbar option fordisplaying images with link text in the Daylight
Experience in Brightspace Learning Environment.
To enable this feature, the d2l.system.BrightspaceDaylightExperience
configuration variable must be turned on.
In addition, the Enable Icon Based Navbarspermissions must be turned on in the Navbar
tool for the appropriate roles.
Next, you must create or edit a navbar thatwill include the image-based navigation.
From the navbar editor, click Enable IconBased Navbar.
When you are ready, click Save and Close.
With this feature turned on, all navbar linkshave a dedicated space for an image above
the link text.System links have default icons with a colorful
Daylight style, and users may also uploadimages for custom links.
This option provides prereaders with a wayto easily navigate Brightspace Learning Environment.
The Daylight Experience now includes a newshortcut to edit or copy navbars directly
from the navbar.
Now, when you hover over the navbar, a shortcutappears.
Click the shortcut, to view a menu where youcan now edit or manage the navbar.
This feature is available for both text-basedand image-based navbars.
Restrictions have been applied to the emailaddress book so users from one section of
a course no longer see users from other sectionsof the course.
This feature partially implements PIE itemsD3652, D3642, D2541, D2001, D1534, and D1477.
If a course is set up so that there is anemail address book for the section, when learners
click the Filter by menu...
the learners listed in the address book arenow filtered by section.
Instructors will continue to see all sectionslisted here if they have Access all Sections
permission.
Lessons is now available to clients in Canada.
Lessons is a new way for instructors and learnersto experience the Content tool in Brightspace
Learning Environment.Previously, Lessons was only available to
US clients. It is now also available to clientsin Canada.
The Lessons experience depends on the DocumentConversion Service, the Activity Feed Service,
and the Learning Outcomes Registry Service.These services depend on the Authentication
Service.For information on data transmission, please
refer to the Microservices documentation.
Instructors can now preview a typical learner’sexperience in the Lessons tool.
To begin, from Lessons, click settings andselect Preview as a Student.
You can now preview the content from a learner'sperspective.
Note: Preview as student does not change theview of the embedded content (for example,
if LTI content has different information forinstructors and learners, instructors will
continue to view the LTI content as an instructor).Click Exit Preview Mode to return to the instructor's
view.
Instructors can create a release conditionor select an existing condition that specifies
that a user must be enrolled in a particularsection to access the content or activity.
When creating or editing a release condition,from the Condition Type dropdown menu, instructors
can now select the Section enrollment optionfrom the Classlist category.
Then, they can click the Section menu to furtherspecify the section.
If the instructor is enrolled in all sectionsor has the Access all sections permission,
they can continue to see all sections in the listwhen creating the new condition.
If the instructor does not have the Accessall Sections permission for their role, the
instructor only sees sections they are enrolledin.
Click Create to apply the release condition.
As a result, instructors are better able torelease content to a section of a course without
impacting other sections.
The Content Service is now available in AWSCanada Central (Montreal), which means the
new SCORM solution is available in Canada.
First, from Organization Tools, ensure theContent Service is turned on and that users
have the appropriate permissions.
In the Config Variable browser, set the d2L.Tools.ContentService.Endpoint
configuration variable to on.
The endpoint URL populates automatically,based on geographic location.
If you had previously set the endpoint URLto a region other than Canada, you can change
the URL to reflect the Canada region.Note: After the AWS region is specified and
SCORM content is added, the region cannotbe changed without data loss. However, if
you change the endpoint and then revert tothe one that your data was stored in previously,
it is possible to reclaim that data.If you already enabled the configuration variable
and set the endpoint URL in a prior release,the region does not change automatically.

title: Question Library - Overview of Question Types - Instructor

captions.text: Create a variety of questions in QuestionLibrary to use for quizzes, self-assessments,
and surveys in your current and future courses.
This tutorial outlines the different questiontypes available in Question Library.
All available question types display whenyou create a new question in Question Library.
Standard question types, such as MultipleChoice and True or False, are available.
You can also create Fill In The Blanks, Ordering,Matching, and Multi-Select questions.
Multi-Select questions differ from multiplechoice in that learners can choose more than
one correct answer.
Utilize short answer or written response optionswhen you want learners to provide detailed
responses to open-ended questions.
The Multi-Short Answer question type providesyou with the opportunity to have multiple
answer boxes all corresponding to a singleanswer set.
This allows you to create only one set ofanswers that the system checks against multiple
responses.
Create significant figures and arithmeticquestions to assess your learners' science
and math knowledge.
Want to see how learners feel about an assessmentthey completed, a module you presented, or
even an entire course?
You can also create Likert questions in QuestionLibrary.
Use these questions in surveys to gauge learnersatisfaction.
Create a variety of questions in QuestionLibrary to use for quizzes, self-assessments,
and surveys in your current and future courses.

title: How to Access and Remove an Old Course | Learner

captions.text: This video explains learners how to access old courses and grades in Brightspace Learning Environment
We'll begin by starting with how to access an old course
After a course ends, you may want to access the course again to review the content and any associated files
However, your ability to access an old course is determined by the following prerequisites:
You are enrolled in the course
The course is set to Active
The course has no date restrictions
The current date is within the available date range of the course
This means that while you may be able to see your previous and upcoming courses on the home page or from the course selector, you likely cannot access those courses
To request access to an old course, contact your course instructor
Course instructors should remove old courses from your view before a new semester starts
If you still see courses from previous semesters, you must contact your instructor for that course to remove it from your homepage
Ask your instructor to de-activate the course
If your instructor isn't available, contact your institution's Help Desk and explain the issue

title: Teaching Tips - Measure How Long a Learner Takes to Complete Quiz Questions - Instructor

captions.text: Evaluate the complexity of a quiz and identifyteaching opportunities by measuring how long
it takes learners to answer quiz questions.This tutorial shows how to measure how long
it takes a learner to complete a set of quizquestions.
Before you can measure the time to completea quiz question, you must create a quiz with
one question per page.By doing so, you can time how long a learner
spends on each page, and thus each question,of the quiz.
To begin, from Quizzes, navigate to the quizcontaining the questions you measure, click
its context menu, and select Grade.From the Users tab, click a learner's quiz
attempt to view how they answered the questions.Then, navigate to the Quiz Results and review
the Save Time for each of the questions.You'll notice that Question 1 was saved at
3:17pm and Question 2 was saved at 3:21pm.Therefore, it took 5 minutes for the learner
to complete the second question.Knowing how long it takes a learner to complete
a quiz question allows you to identify wherelearners may need help as well as better design
similar quiz questions in future quizzes.Evaluate the complexity of a quiz and identify
teaching opportunities by measuring how longit takes learners to answer quiz questions.

title: Quick Eval - Grade Submissions using Quick Eval - Instructor

captions.text: Find and prioritize unevaluated learner submissionsusing Quick Eval.
This tutorial shows how to identify unevaluatedlearner submissions in Quick Eval.
In Quick Eval, all ungraded submissions display.Sort submissions by first and last name, activity
name, or Submission Date.You can also filter results. Click Filter.
Here you can filter by activity name, by selectingor searching for an activity,
or by the last 24 hours, Last 48 hours, Last7 days or Older than 7 days.
Note: You can use multiple filters to organizelearner submissions.
For this example, filter by activity name…
and select Classify the Sunspots.
Click elsewhere on the screen to close thefilter.
To evaluate submissions, click a learnersname.
Evaluate the submission.
You can publish the learners score, or savedraft.
For this example Save Draft.
To return to Quick Eval. Click back to QuickEval.
A draft icon will appear next to a learnersname when an evaluation is saved as draft.
As you complete and publish evaluations theywill no longer appear in Quick Eval.
When all evaluations have been completed Quick Eval will display an You are all caught up message.
Find and prioritize unevaluated learner submissionsusing Quick Eval.

title: Navigate Brightspace Learning Environment - Engage in Discussions - Learner

captions.text: Share thoughts and comments on course topicsin the Discussions tool.
This tutorial shows how to navigate the Discussionstool in Brightspace Learning Environment.
Discussions are your course message boards,which are organized into forums and topics.
Forums are categories that organize topics.Click on a topic to view and reply to threads.
Note: This area may look different dependingon the view options available at your organization
and which one you choose in Settings.Click Start New Thread to create a new message.
Enter a subject and message.You can also attach files and make audio recordings
for your message.Click Post to add your message to the discussion.
Click the thread's context menu if you wantto edit, delete, or complete other actions.
Click the Subscribed icon to subscribe toand unsubscribe from threads.
You can also subscribe to an forum or topic.Click the context menu for the forum or topic
and select subscribe.Then, select a notification method and click
Subscribe to confirm.You can customize how you receive notifications
for all discussion forums and topics by accessingNotifications from your personal menu.
Share thoughts and comments on course topicsin Discussions.

title: Instructor Release Highlights - August 2019 v.20.19.08

captions.text: This video highlights some of the new and updated features of Brightspace Learning Environment 20.19.08.
As part of our ongoing commitment to design and develop against WC3 accessibility best
practices, we have updated our shared web components to align with WCAG 2.1 standards.
For a full list of changes review the release notes.
An underline has been added to the Post Type to better differentiate between Message and Assignment posts,
and field names have been added to improve accessibility.
From Activity Feed, when selecting between
Message and Assignment posts, your selectionis now underlined to better indicate the post type.
When creating a Message or Assignment, a field
name has been added to improve accessibility.The post type icon has been removed to provide
more authoring space when creating posts.Once a post is published, the new layout makes
more efficient use of screen space.
Text within comment annotations is now checked for spelling mistakes.
To better align with WCAG 2.1 level AA criteria,
we have removed the OpenDyslexic font. Foradditional information, review the release notes.
Class Progress now includes an Outcomes tab.
The Outcomes tab will display a history oflearner’s submissions and assessments against
all learning outcomes aligned to activitiesin the course.
The Outcomes tab will display a history oflearner’s submissions and assessments against
all learning outcomes aligned to activitiesin the course. Click Learning Outcomes.
To view a list of associated learning outcomes.You will also see a visual indicator
of outcome achievement, if your organizationhas implemented achievement scales.
Users can select Insert Image to add picturesto an email from their device, a URL, or Manage
Files. Images are inserted in place, attachedto the email, and display in place.
This feature implements PIE items D871, D5458,and D2163.
When composing an email Insert Stuff has beenreplaced with Insert Image. Click it….
and select how you will attach your image.For this example, click My Computer.
Drag and drop the image onto the upload target,or as in this example click Upload.
When you are ready, click Add.
Your image displays inline.
Intelligent Agents now re-evaluate the statusof release conditions at the moment of triggering
to determine whether a user has completeda particular release condition or not.
This feature implements pie item D3497.
The new Quiz Builder experience is now generally
available and recommended for use in productionenvironments. If you do not have access, contact
your Brightspace Administrator.
Navigate to Quiz Questions…
and click Add/Edit Questions.
Here you can access the new Quiz Builder Experience
to Add, Import or select and delete questionsin the quiz.
Questions can be rearranged using the handles to drag and drop,
or can be moved using keyboard only navigation.
Deleted quiz attempts can now be restored using the Quiz Attempt Log.
From Quizzes, click the context menu of the quiz attempt you want to restore.
Navigate to Attempt Logs…
...and click it.
To restore a quiz, click Restore.
A new AutoAnalysis tool has been added tothe Video Assignments Premium integration
by Bongo. This new tool provides English transcriptionand analysis of clarity, filter words and
speaking rate in words per minute. This newtool is available to all clients with the
Video Assignments Premium integration.
The Virtual Table of Contents widget now displays
the optimal number of modules in the widgetand adds a button for navigation between pages.
Did the Quiz Builder feature catch your eye?Check out our new Create and Edit a Quiz using
Quiz Builder video now! And don't forget to subscribe!

title: Intelligent Agents - Perform a Practice Run - Instructor

captions.text: Discover which users an intelligent agentwould identify, without sending out an alert
email, by performing a practice run.
This tutorial shows how to perform a practicerun for intelligent agents.
To begin, from Intelligent Agents, click thecontext menu of the agent you want to perform
a practice run on.and select Practice Run.
A confirmation displays.
Click Run to continue.
Note: You will receive an email confirmation once the Intelligent Agent has completed its run.
Click done to return to the Intelligent Agentspage.
The agent will now display a Last Run Dateof just now.
Click Number of Users Identified...to view the users identified by the practice run...
and no action is taken.
Discover which users an intelligent agentwould identify, without sending out an alert
email, by performing a practice run.

title: Teaching Tips - Use Self Assessments as Study Aids - Instructor

captions.text: Ease learners into the online learning experienceand reduce their test anxiety by familiarizing
them with various question types using selfassessments.
This tutorial shows how to create a self assessmentto deliver as a pre-assessment study aid.
To begin, from Self Assessments, click NewSelf Assessment.
Enter a name. Tip: Use categories
to organize assessments based on similarities.
Add a category, if desired.
You can create a category or select an existing one from the Category menu.
If you design your questions to include hints,click Allow Hints. Tip: Design question hints
that give learners suggestions on how to approachthe question.
Then, click Save.Next, click Add/Edit Questions.
Click Import...and select a source.
Select the questions you want to include inthe self assessment. Note: All point values
are removed when importing questions fromQuestion Library to Self Assessments.
Tip: When creating questions for self assessments,include links to additional resources in the
Feedback section to aid in content comprehension.When you are ready, click Add.
Then, click Done Editing Questions.Lastly, click Save and Close.
Your self assessment displays. Tip: In Content,create quicklinks to self assessments to track
which learners are accessing the material.
Ease learners into the online learning experience and reduce their test anxiety by familiarizing them with
various types using self assessments

title: Content - Import a Course - Instructor

captions.text: Conveniently import components from other systems, provided by content vendors, or created
in a content creation program directly intoyour course.
This tutorial shows how to import componentsinto your course.
To begin, from the Table of Contents click,Import Course.
You can copy an existing course, or you canimport a course package.
In this example, we will import a course package.
For more information on what a course package is and what formats are supported,
click the corresponding links.
When you are ready, drag and drop the file onto the upload target.
Click Import All Components.
The import begins. Follow the status of theimport by reviewing the progress bar.
A confirmation displays when the import iscomplete. You can then import another package
or view the imported content. In this example,we will view the content.
The imported contents display in Content.Note: If you import course components with
names that already exist in the course, duplicatenames will appear, and will not be overwritten.
Conveniently import components from othersystems, provided by content vendors, or created
in a content creation program directly intoyour course.

title: Brightspace Capture™ - Create Live Event - Instructor

captions.text: Create a live event to make an upcoming webcastto make its details, access links, and URL
available to viewers.This tutorial shows how to create and schedule
a live event in Capture Portal.Before viewers can watch a live webcast, a
live event must be created. Live events canbe created in similar ways in both Capture
Portal and Capture Central.To begin, log in to Capture Portal and click
Admin. Note that the Admin page will onlybe available once you are logged in.
Click Create Live EventEnter a title for the event.
Then, enter the name of the presenter.You can also enter a description and tags
to provide more information about the event.Now, set the event's date, start time, and
end time.You can modify the presentation's layout settings,
but the presenter is able to change thesesettings when they begin their webcast.
Click Access Control to view and edit thesettings that determine who has access to
the webcast.Select Event Password Required to set a password
for the presentation. If you set a password,viewers must enter the password you have specified
before gaining access to the presentation.You can also disable the chat feature, disable
the viewer limit, or change the limit on thenumber of viewers.
In the permissions area you can set permissionsfor specific users, groups, and roles. By
default the live event's permissions are setso that all users, including those without
Capture accounts, can view the event. Forthis example we will change the permissions
so that only authenticated users with Captureaccounts can view this event.
To begin, search for the Authenticated Users.Select Authenticated Users form the list.
We will leave the permissions set to Can Viewbecause we want authenticated users to be
able to view the presentation, but not manageor edit it.
Click the delete icon to remove the settingthat grants Everyone presentation viewing
permission.When you are ready click Create.
A live event has been created.Create a live event to make an upcoming webcast’s
details, access links, and URL available toviewers.

title: Brightspace for Parents - Monitor Homework - Parents

captions.text: Help your children with their assessmentsby reviewing Upcoming Assignments, Recent
Grades, and Assignment Details.This tutorial shows how to navigate the homework
related pages of Brightspace for Parents.From your child's dashboard, the Overdue Alerts
widget informs you of any missed work. TheUpcoming Work section assignment specifics
including the class it relates to, the typeof assessment, and the due date. A checkmark
in this section shows that your child submittedan assignment. Click View All Work....
to see a bi-weekly view of current and upcomingassignments, their due dates, and their completion
status. You can navigate the weekly calendarusing the dates dropdown menu. Click Back
to Dashboard to return to it.The Recent Grades section gives you a look
at your child's recently awarded grades. ClickView all grades...
to view detailed grades by assessment or overallcourse grades for you child. Click view feedback
to see any instructor-provided feedback fora course or assignment.
Click Back to Dashboard.To view assignment details, click an assignment.
Note: You can access the Assignment Detailspage from Upcoming Work and Recent Grades.
Assignment Details include the status, outof score or earned grade if applicable, instructions,
relevant dates....and supporting materials.
You can also view rubric feedback, if applicable...and the files your child submitted.
Help your children with their assessmentsby reviewing Upcoming Assignments, Recent
Grades, and Assignment Details.

title: Discussions - Discussion Statistics - Instructor

captions.text: Gain insight into who is posting, and which topics are generating the most interest using discussion statistics.
This tutorial shows how to use discussion statistics.
To begin, from Discussions, click Statistics.
You can Export to CSV, review statistics by Users or by Forums and Topics.
When you view statistics by user, you will see an overall Org Unit summary, have the ability to view by User,
Sections, or Groups, search for a specific user, or browse your classlist.
You are presented with a post interaction break down for each user.
Click Forums and Topics.
This allows you to review interaction and engagement on a forum or topic basis.
Select a Topic name to see more specific data.
Learner specific data is available.
Gain insight into who is posting, and which topics are generating the most interest using discussion statistics.

title: Grades - Exemptions Overview - Instructor

captions.text: Accommodate the different needs of learnersby creating topic and assignment exemptions
This video provides an overview of how exemptions interact with Content, Class Progress, and Assignments.
To begin setting exemptions, from Content,
click Bulk Edit.Navigate to the topic you want to exempt learners
from...click "Edit restrictions for"
and then, click Manage Exemptions.
select the learner(s) to be exempted...and click Exempt.
The Exempt Status column updates to reflectthe new exemption. To return to Content, click
Close...and then click Update.
Repeat this process as necessary to exemptlearners from topics.
The learner's course schedule updates andreflects exemptions in topic titles, and removes
completion method indicators.When viewing Content, the Table of Contents
and module completion tracking reflects thenew number of required topics and topic names
highlight the exemption.When a learner accesses an exempted topic,
the learner is directed to a new page thatrestates the exemption and provides access
to the content.
When you view an assignment submission folder
with exemptions attached...learners still can to submit work to the folder.
A learner, who submits work when exempted,is identified with (Exempt) following their
name. If you click the assignment to providefeedback.
Additional exemption reminders display inthe Evaluation panel.
When learners view Assignments, they can nowsee updated titles indicating an exemption.
When learners view Grades, they can see Exemptin the Grade column as well as an updated
grade item title.In a leaner's Progress Summary, Content and
Grade exemptions display in the respectivetabs. Click Content.
Navigate to and expand the unit with exemptionsassociated with its topics.
To view the topics the learner is exempt from.Accommodate the different needs of learners
by creating topic and assignment exemptionsin Content.

title: Quizzes - View and Understand the Submission View - Learner

captions.text: Review quiz questions, their answers, andinstructor feedback from the submission view
of a quiz.This tutorial shows how to read the feedback
provided in a quiz's submission view.The submission views may be immediately available
after submitting a quiz, or from Class Progressat a later time.
Submission views help you to review the resultsof a quiz and may include: questions answered
correctly, questions answered incorrectly,questions without responses, questions with
responses, and the correct answer.When reviewing a question in the submission
view,checkmarks indicate your answer. X's indicate
incorrect answers, and arrows indicate correctanswers as set by the instructor.
Navigate to...and click Done to exit the submission view.
Review quiz questions, their answers, andinstructor feedback from the submission view
of a quiz.

title: Discussions - Lock a Forum - Instructor

captions.text: Lock a discussion forum to turn it into aread only archive for your learners.
This tutorial shows how to prevent the creationor modification of posts by locking a discussion forum.
You can lock discussions at the forum, and topic levels.
For this example, we will lockan existing discussion forum.
Click the context menu of the forum you want to lock.
Then, select Edit Forum.
Navigate to the Restrictions tab.
Then navigate to Locking Options.
By default, forum and topics are unlocked.
You can lock forums at any time by selecting Lock Forum.
Or you can select Unlock Forumfor a specific date range.
This allows learners to still view the forum, but not engage with it outside of the defined date range.
For this example, select Lock Forum.
Then, click Save and Close.
The Locked icon will display to indicate the forum is now read only.
When a learner views a locked Forum all existing posts are visible,
and they no longer have access to create a post.
Lock a discussion forum to turn it into a read only archive for your learners.

title: Release Highlights - September 2017 (version 10.7.5) - Administrator

captions.text: This video highlights some of the new and updated features of Brightspace Learning Environment 10.7.5.
Instructors can now easily direct learners
to reference materials or resources requiredto complete an assignment by adding links,
existing activities, and Google Drive filesas attachments to an Activity Feed post.
When creating an assignment post, four optionsare available for attaching resources to an
assignment post: File Upload, Attach Linkto Existing Activity, Attach Weblink,
and Attach from Google Drive.Now, instructors can also add links, existing
activities, and Google Drive files as attachmentsto an assignment submission folder.
When creating or editing an assignment submissionfolder, click Add Attachment to select from
four options available for attaching resourcesto an assignment post: File, Link, Existing
Activity, and Google Drive.Note: To disable use of the Google Drive option
in Assignments, ensure that the org levelconfig variable
d2l.3rdParty.GoogleDrive.EnableGooglePicker
is set to off.The Awards tool has been updated to provide
a more consistent Brightspace Daylight experience.This feature implements PIE item D2945.
The floating menu at the top of the Awardstool now has the search filters on the right
side and the search bar on the left side.On the Course Awards area, references to Mozilla
no longer appear in the floating menu.To view the details of an award, users now
click the image.Updates to all confirmation dialogs include
a Yes or No response to proceed.Links such as Save, Close, Previous, Next,
Delete, and Preview have been replaced withicon buttons.
Updates include the appearance of Save andClose controls on all appropriate dialogs
and popup windows.Aesthetic changes to conform with Daylight
look and feel, such as smaller and updatedicons, updates to fonts, font weights, and
alignment, formatting on popups, and dominantcontrols colored blue, have been added.
Updates to menus in the Awards tool are moreresponsive to align with Daylight Experience
styling, size, and scrolling behavior.Lastly, Awards now features more responsive
views for tablets and mobile devices.Instructors can now create new topics in Lessons
by adding a URL.To create new topics by adding a URL, click Link.
Instructors then enter a secure link and the name they want the link to display as.
Then, instructors can select whether they
want the link to appear embedded on the pageor open in a new tab.
Instructors can now upload files to the QuestionLibrary and review them without leaving the
Question Library, Survey, Self-Assessment,or Quiz creation workflow.
Now, when instructors import questions toQuestion Library, an option is available to
Upload a File.The Import File menu has been updated.
Add a CSV or ZIP file by dragging and droppingit on the upload target, or browsing to the
file.When the file has uploaded, click Review to
preview the content from the upload.Ensure you select all questions you want to
import.Then, click Import All (or Import Selected)
when you are ready to import the questions.

title: Import/Export/Copy Components - Import Components - Instructor

captions.text: Conveniently import components from othersystems, provided by content vendors, or created
in a content creation program directly intoyour course.
This tutorial shows how to import componentsinto a course.
To begin, from the Import/Export/Copy Componentspage, select Import Components.
Click start to begin the import process.For more information on what a course package
is and what formats are supported, click thecorresponding links.
When you are ready, drag and drop the fileonto the upload target.
Click Import All Components.The import begins. Follow the status of the
import by reviewing the progress bar.A confirmation displays when the import is
complete. You can then import another packageor view the imported content. In this example,
we will view the content.The imported components display in Content.
Conveniently import components from othersystems, provided by content vendors, or created
in a content creation program directly intoyour course.

title: Awards - Create a Badge - Instructor

captions.text: Recognize the accomplishments of your learnersby adding badges to your course.
This tutorial shows how to create a badgeand add it to your course.
To begin, from Awards, click Course Awards.Here you can view any existing badges or certificates.
To add a badge to your course, click Add Award to course.
Here, you can add an existing award, or createa new one. For this example, click Create.
Enter a name…and enter a description for the award.
Select the award type. Award types includebadges and certificates. For this example,
leave Badge selected, and navigate to availability.In Availability, you can choose to share your
awards with other courses, with other awardscreators, or restrict their use to child org
units. You may also change the award’s expiry settings.
Next, choose an image for the badge’s icon. You can choose an existing image, upload a
new one, or create a new image to upload.For this example, click Upload New Icon.
Browse for, and select the image, when youare ready, click Open.
Your image displays. Make any necessary modificationsto the award issuer information. When you
are ready, click Save and Close.The newly created badge appears in the Course
Awards list. You can not award it to learnersmanually from the Classlist Awards page. Or,
from Edit Properties, you can add releaseconditions that will automatically award the
badge to learners when the release conditionsare met.
Recognize the accomplishments of your learnersby adding badges to your course.

title: Concepts for Administrators - Higher Education Organization Structure - Administrators

captions.text: The organization or "org" structure is a hierarchicalstructure comprised of individual org units
that are arranged in parent-child relationships.
This tutorial provides an example overviewof a basic org structure and its org units
while discussing how you can use this structureto organize your higher education institution
in D2L Learning Environment.
This is an example of a basic org structure.
The organization, department, course template,and course offering org units are required.
All other org units are optional ways to definethe hierarchy.
We will discuss each org unit individually.
First, we will discuss the organization orgunit, which is highlighted in orange.
The organization org unit – also known asthe “My Home” page in D2L Learning Environment
– is the highest level of the structureand represents your entire institution.
At this level, you can define elements thatwill be common to all users throughout the
entire institution, such as the default homepage.
For this example, we look at the org structurefor the fictional University of Springfield.
Next, we'll look at custom org units.
You can tailor custom org units to createan additional level or levels of structure
between the organization and department orgunits.
For example, custom org units could dividethe organization into distinct campuses or
schools.
These optional org units can be parallel orhierarchical to each other.
If you have multiple campuses, it can be helpfulto divide your org structure by these locations
if they host a unique set of course offerings.
For example, the main campus and the medialab are custom org units that comprise the
overall institution.
Departments are mandatory org units that dividethe org level or custom org units.
Department org units organize courses andlearners within the overall hierarchy.
You can define these org units however you’dlike.
For example, a department org unit can representa subject or progress level.
In this example, the department org unitshouse–the English and Anthropology departments.
Next, we will discuss course templates.
Course templates add an extra level of structurebetween departments and course offerings.
They act as a container that collects relatedcourse offerings.
Note: Course templates and course offeringshave a parent-child relationship.
Course offerings must be the child of a coursetemplate.
For example, University of Springfield offersa multitude of English classes, including
English 101 and English 200.
Course templates group together courses offeringsthat fall within these categories.
Next, we will discuss course offerings.
Course offerings are the courses in whichlearners are enrolled and where they access
their learning materials.
In general, a course offering is populatedby instructors.
Learners access course offerings from theorganization homepage using the course selector
on the minibar.
In this example, the Grade 5 band class hasa Fall 2015 and Winter 2016 offering.
You can further subdivide course offeringsinto sections.
Sections allow administrators or instructorsto divide a Course Offering's roster into
chunks.
This is especially useful for dividing largerosters into more manageable units.
One course offering can be subdivided intomultiple sections.
In this example, English 200A is subdividedinto two sections to manage the large number
of learners enrolled in the course.
Groups provide an additional layer of structureto the hierarchy.
Groups divide a course offering for the purposeof group work.
You can create multiple categories for groups,and enroll learners into one or more groups.
Sections divide the classlist into distinctchunks.
Groups allow organized collaboration.
In this example, the class is divided intotwo collaborative groups for a project.
Finally, we will discuss semesters.
Semesters are an optional org unit.
You can use semesters to divide course offeringsinto time-based categories.
Dividing course offerings into semesters allowsadministrators to search for course offerings
that are being offered within a specifiedtime period.
For this example, the org structure depictsthe course offerings for the Fall 2014 semester.
Org structures are flexible in their composition.
You can custom-make org units to best fityour institution.
This is an example of an out-of-the-box organizationstructure.
You can customize additional org units tostructure your institution.
As a best practice, you should liaise withD2L Implementation Consultants to design and
create the ideal organization structure.

title: ePortfolio - Use Tag Lists to Add Items to a Collection - Learner

captions.text: Curate your items in Brightspace ePortfolio using tag lists.
This tutorial shows how to create a tag listthat automatically populates a collection.
To begin, from the ePortfolio dashboard, clickthe My Items tab.
Then, click the context menu of the collectionto which you want to add the items.
Select Edit.Browse to the Items in Collection section...
...and click Add to Collection.You can add items to the collection manually,
or automatically using a tag list. Click TagList.
