Quiz scores and feedback entered in Grades is now synchronized to display in both tools.
Note: Synchronization only occurs for new grade entries.
This feature implements PIE item D391.
When creating new rubrics at the org level, users can share the rubric with other org units.
When creating rubrics at the org level there is a new option Make rubric available to.
Here, you can specify which org units can apply this rubric to assessments in their courses.
Personal info fields in the User Profile page are now limited to 4000 characters.
Thanks for watching, we are always looking to hear from you about the videos you'd like to see.
Drop us a comment below, and as always don't forget to subscribe!

title: Competencies - Overview - Instructor

captions.text: Competency structures are used to track information about the knowledge, skills, and abilities
learners acquire.
They can be used to help access learning outcomes,and formalize course and program requirements
for accreditation.
This tutorial provides an overview of competencystructures.
In Competencies you can view, edit, and createcompetency structures.
Competency structures are formed by organizingcompetencies, learning objectives, and activities
into a hierarchy.
Competencies occupy the highest levels ofthese hierarchies.
They represent general knowledge, skills,and abilities that learners can acquire.
Note that your organization might use differentterminology to describe competencies.
They might instead be called proficiencies,learning outcomes, standards, and skills.
Learning objectives occupy middle positionsin competency structures.
They represent specific knowledge, skillsand abilities that a learner must acquire
in order to gain a competency.
Again your organization might use differentterminology, calling them indicators, criteria,
requirements, or learning outcomes.
Activities occupy the lowest level of competencystructures.
These include quizzes, surveys, assignments,discussions, and more.
Activities are the only elements that canbe assessed in a competency structure, and
they provide a basis for determining whena learner has achieved parent learning objectives.
A competency structure hierarchy results from parent-child relationships between the structure’s elements.
Competencies can only have other competenciesas parents.
They can have both learning objectives andother competencies as children.
Learning objectives may have both competenciesand other learning objectives as parents,
and both learning objectives and activitiesas children.
Activities can only have learning objects as parents and can't have any elements as children.
In the navigation pane an example competencystructure is displayed.
In this simple structure the competency hasone learning objective as a child, and this
learning objective has two activities as itschildren.
More complex competency structures can becreated.
Note that a single element can have multipleparents...
...and it can also have multiple children.
Competencies can be created within a courseoffering, but they can also be created in
higher org units, such as departments andsemesters, and shared with multiple course
offerings.
This allows your organization to track userachievements across multiple semesters and
courses.
Competency structures are used to track informationabout the knowledge, skills, and abilities
learners acquire.

title: Grades Tool – Schemes

captions.text: From the organizational homepage, select thedesired course using the My Courses widget
or the Course Selector icon at the top of the page.
From your course level Navbar, select Grades to access the Grades tool.
You can also access the Grades tool through your Course Admin link if you do not have the grades link on your course Navbar.
From the Grades tool, select Schemes under the top navigation bar.
To review an organization scheme that youradministration has created and its properties,
click the name of the scheme from the Organization Schemes list.
You can also review which scheme has been set as the default for new assessments,
and to choose a new default, click the check marks in the Set as Default column.
Once you select the organization scheme, youcan now view the Name, Short Name,
Symbol (which is the symbol or text to be displayedin the Grades tool when a grade has been set),
Examples or Letter Grades, Pass/Fail and Proficiency,
Start Percentage (this defines the starting threshold for the symbol to be applied when a grade of set),
Color (which allows for color to be displayed in the Grades tool for quickly identifying grade trends),
Assign Value Percentage (this will define the numeric grade you want learners to achieve when you evaluate them using the grade scheme).
To save changes, click Save and Close, or Cancel to return to the previous page.
To create a new scheme, click New Scheme.
Fill in the scheme details including Name, Short Name, and Ranges.
Ranges include Symbol, Start Percentage, Color, Assigned Value Percentage.
Additional ranges can be created by entering the desired number of ranges to be added and clicking Add Ranges.
Ranges can also be deleted by clicking theTrash icon under the Remove column.
Click Save and Close to exit.
To copy or delete schemes, select the MoreActions drop-down menu to copy existing schemes
or delete custom schemes that have been created within your course.
Organizational schemes can only be deletedby administrators with appropriate permissions.

title: Quizzes - Customize Question Delivery using Quiz Builder - Instructor

captions.text: Customize question delivery to add structureto your quizzes and increase assessment integrity
using the Quiz Builder. This tutorial showshow to create sections and question pools
using Quiz Builder.To begin, from Quizzes, click the context
menu of the quiz you want to edit……and select edit.
Navigate to Quiz Questions.Then click, Add/Edit Questions
Here, you can increase the structure of yourquiz and reduce cheating by creating sections.
Sections allow you to group related questions,and can be randomized. To create a section,
click Add.and select Section.
Enter a Title. Additionally, you can add optionalcontextual information in Section Text.
Hide section details using the correspondingHide Section Title and Hide Section Text from
students checkboxes. To randomize questiondelivery within the section, click Shuffle
questions in this section. When you are ready,click Save.
Add questions to your section by draggingand dropping them into place using the Handles
or using keyboard only navigation. For thisexample, we will move a question using the
arrow keys on the keyboard.Questions in sections appear indented to identify
they have been added to the section successfully.Additionally, you can improve quiz integrity
by creating question pools. Click Add.Then, select Question Pool.
Question pools show each learner a differentset of random questions from a larger pool
of questions with each attempt.Give the Question Pool a title…
Then, specify the number of questions to bedisplayed to learners, and the points value
that will be assigned to all questions inthe pool.
To add questions, click Browse Question Library.Select the questions to include…
and click add.When you are ready, click Save.
Your Question Pool displays, and indicatesthe position in the quiz, how many questions
will be displayed out of how many questionsare available, and how many points each question
is worth, for quick reference.Customize question delivery to add structure
to your quizzes and increase assessment integrityusing the Quiz Builder.

title: Content - Add a SCORM Object - Instructor

captions.text: Enrich the content available in your courseby uploading a SCORM object.
This tutorial shows how to add a SCORM objectto a content module.
To begin, from Content, navigate to the moduleor submodule where you want to add a SCORM
object.Then, click Upload/Create.
and select, New SCORM ObjectYou can search for existing objects, or upload
a new one. For this example, click Upload.Click the upload target to open the file browser,
or drag and drop the file onto the target.Note: You can upload up to 50 SCORM objects at once.
The upload begins...From Edit Properties you can change the name
of the file, edit the sharing options, andaccess advanced properties. Click the Name
of file field to change the name.Click Advanced Properties.
To select your navigation options based onthe whether your SCORM object has built in
navigation. By default, Do not add externalnavigation. My file has built in navigation.
is selected. When you are ready, click Save.Select the newly uploaded SCORM object.
Then, click Add.Select whether you want to create a grade
item for the SCORM object. For this example,leave yes selected.
Click the Grade Calculation Method dropdown...and select your preferred grading method.
Then, if desired, change your version controloptions. If you want the SCORM object to stay
the same as it was when you uploaded it selectDisplay this version even if a new version
is added. For this example, we will leaveAlways display the latest version selected,
this updates the content as new versions areadded. When you are ready, click Add.
Your SCORM object displays. Click Open InNew Window to view it.
Enrich the content available in your courseby uploading a SCORM object.

title: December 2022/20.22.12 Release Highlights Video

captions.text: This video is a selection of the new and updatedfeatures we're excited to share with you from
the December 2022 Release.
The full list of features can be found inthe December 2022 Version 20.22.12 Release
Notes, which you can find on Brightspace Community.
This month we’re highlighting the followingfeatures:
Consolidate availability dates using the Quizzestool.
Data Hub has added columns to BrightspaceData Sets for Assignments.
In Lessons, the new create and edit experiencefor activities is now default in New Content
Experience.
And finally, a summary of changes for allthe other features this month.
Let’s take a closer look at this month’sfeatures!
Instructors can now include availability datesin the Calendar and have greater control over
the behavior of availability dates for theirlearners.
As a result, instructors can:Prevent late submissions;
Allow learners to view assignment informationand submissions either without being able
to attempt it or after the end date; andSchedule the visibility of an assignment and
post start and end dates of an assignmentto the Calendar.
In Assignments, select or create an assignmentand enter a Due Date.
Under Availability Dates & Conditions, entereither a start date, an end date, or both.
Click the Before Start or After End link andselect an availability option.
Click done, and then click Save and Close.
The Assignments feature implements the followingPIE Items:
D1396, D1746, D3398, and D6797 (Dropbox availabilityto match dates set by instructor);
D8004 (Add lock dates for assignments andquizzes);
D2536 and D8173 (Schedule visibility of assignments);D3153, D3670, D4900, D4958, and D7195 (Allow
learners to view assignment information andfeedback after assignment is closed);
D1672, D4217 and D7273 (Post Assignment andDiscussion Start and End Dates in Calendar
and Upcoming Events).
Thank you to all those who put forward thesePIE suggestions to implement this feature!
The Assignments feature is available to allclients.
To enable, ensure that the configuration variabled2l.Tools.Dropbox.ConsistentDatesEnabled (OrgUnit)
is set to ON.
By default, this is set to OFF.
This release adds new columns to both theAssignment Summary and Assignment Special
Access Brightspace Data Sets:StartDateAvailabilityType (which determines
whether learners can view or access the assignmentbefore its start date); and
EndDateAvailabilityType (which determineswhether learners can view or access the assignment
after its end date).
The new columns in Assignment Summary havea default value of 0 (meaning 'access restricted')
for all assignments with availability datescreated before December 2022 (There is no
historical data available for Assignment SpecialAccess).
The Learner Usage Advanced Data Set respectsthe new date settings on assignments when
calculating the Content Required and ContentCompleted column values.
The Data Hub feature is available to all clients.
To enable, ensure that the d2l.Tools.BrightspaceDataSets.Versionconfiguration variable is set to Version 7
and that the Can Access Brightspace Data Setspermission is granted to administrators at
the org level.
The new experience for creating and editingcontent topics and modules with the New Content
Experience (Lessons) is now the default.
The option for instructors to opt out of thenew create and edit experience for activities
is removed.
Instructors who previously opted out now seethe new experience.
Optionally, the configuration variable d2l.Tools.Content.LessonsCreateExperienceOptIncan be overridden if users wish for instructors
to have the option to opt out.
This feature is available to all clients usingthe New Content Experience (Lessons) and is
automatically enabled.
The configuration variable d2l.Tools.Content.LessonsCreateExperienceOptIncan be changed to OFF if users do not want
to adopt the experience or to ON (Opt-in)if users wish for instructors to be able to
opt out of the new experience.
Finally, let’s take a quick look at theother features for this month’s release.
Additional control over message alerts nowallows hiding of mail and instant messages
from message alerts with Brightspace AdministrativeTools and Configs.
The Discussions tool features improved discussiontopic creation and edit workflows in the New
Content Experience, as well as the abilityto reach every learner with the introduction
of ReadSpeaker text-to-speech technology.
Manage training and engaging learning experienceswith decentralized workflows using Brightspace
Extended Administration.
Improved consistency with the removal of legacyscheduling options in the Intelligent Agents
tool.
Quicklinks allows users to easily find audio-videocontent with improved Quicklink filters.
In Quizzes, the new create and edit experienceis set to On (Opt-in) by default.
And finally, removal of legacy Rubric assessmenttype for learning objectives associated with
quizzes implemented in the Rubrics tool.
We hope you enjoyed this month’s releasehighlights.
As before, you can get the full details ofthis month’s changes in the December 2022
/ Version 20.22.12 Release Notes on BrightspaceCommunity.
See you next month!

title: Data Hub - Set up Advanced Data Sets - Administrator

captions.text: Access, filter, and export pre-defined collectionsof data from the Brightspace platform to further
analyze that data according to your needs.
This tutorial shows how to set up and exportAdvanced Data Sets.
Ensure that Data Hub is enabled prior to settingup a data set.
Advanced Data Sets are comprised of more complexdata sets that join and aggregate data across
multiple tables from Brightspace LearningEnvironment; these data sets are available
to Brightspace Insights and Brightspace Coreclients.
Advanced Data Sets help you understand moreabout the activity and success of instructors
and learners in your organization, including:All Grades, Course Learning Outcome Evaluation,
Instructor Usage, and Learner Usage.
To set up Advanced Data Sets, click the AdminTools menu and select Roles and Permissions.
To ensure you have control over who has accessto your important data, you must set up the
permissions for the data extracts.
Click the role you want to be able to viewthe data sets.
Typically, this will be an administrator.
Click the Filter by Tool drop-down list and select Advanced Data Sets.
Then, click Apply Filter.
Grant the permissions, at the Organizationlevel, that correspond to the data set you
want the user to be able to run.
When you are ready, click Save.
If you are using the Course Learning OutcomeEvaluation data set, you will also need to
set ProgramOrgUnitTypeId configuration variable.
Click the Admin Tools menu and select ConfigVariable Browser.
Navigate to the config variable by clickingTools, AdvancedDataSets, ProgramOrgUnitTypeId.
Then, click Edit.
Find the Org Unit Type ID by accessing theapplicable Edit Org Unit Type page from the
Org Unit Type Editor and viewing the ID inthe URL.
Enter the org unit type ID for the org unitsthat hold the competency parents of the course
learning objecitves.
Then, click Save.
Once you have set the permissions and configvariable, you can export an Advanced Data
Set.
From the navbar, click Data Hub.
From the Data Sets tab, click the data setyou want to export.
Filter the data set as needed.
For example, enter an Org Unit ID and selectroles to include.
When you are ready, click Export.
From the Job Status tab, you can view thestatus of the export.
When the data set is available, click Completein the Status category to download it.
Unzip the data set package and open the CSVfile with a CSV-compatible software.
You can use the CSV file containing the dataset to analyze that data according to your
needs.
Access, filter, and export predefined collectionsof data from the Brightspace platform to further
analyze that data according to your needs.

title: Release Highlights - September 2019 v. 20.19.09 - Administrator

captions.text: This video highlights some of the new and updated features of Brightspace Learning Environment 20.19.09.
Activity Feed posts display remote plug-in quicklinks inline as embedded attachments and no longer
require navigation to view.
Instructors and Learners can now paste embed codes directly into message posts.
When creating a new message post, enter your message, and copy your embed code
into Create a Message.
Clean up your message by removing the HTML.
The embed code automaticallyattaches and displays inline.
Users can now attach web links to message and assignment posts.
Copy the weblink into Create a Message.
Clean up your message by removing the weblink.
Then click Post.
If applicable, a thumbnail and description of the weblink display inline.
Instructors grading assignment submissions from Grades will now see their evaluation in Assignments.
Note: Existing grade data for assignment submissions are not migrated. The synchronization only occurs
for new grade entries. This feature implements PIE items D3610, and D0391.
Improvements have been made to Assignments. You can now set the desired default behavior of ON/OFF
for annotations with the new d2l.Tools.Assignments.AnnotationsDefault
configuration variable.
This new configuration variable manages the default state of the
Make annotation tools available for assessment check box if annotations are enabled for that course.
This release introduces user-tied tool preferences. When instructors select the tools, such as annotations,
to use in an assignment submission, Brightspace remembers those preferences and will carry them
through subsequent assignment creations.
When navigating back, or closing a browser, a new Failure to Save notification warning appears prompting
instructors to save their changes, or actively choose to proceed without saving.
This feature implements PIE items D5321, D5611, D5450, D5367, and D5229.
Several updates have been made to the Assessment Quality Dashboard. The dashboard now includes quizzes
with question pools, a new column in the question statistics table that indicates if the question is part
of a question pool, and the Quiz Survey Sections Brightspace Data Set now has a Version column to
support Question Pools information in the Assessment Quality Dashboard. Note: Question Pool data will take
two weeks to migrate following this update.
To help keep learners up to date on course activity, Brightspace Pulse now displays Activity Feed
notifications in the Updates tab.
You can now control the visibility of the available Class and User Progress indicators.
The Modify Org Default Progress Indicators permission must be set at the org level.
From Class Progress and User Progress Settings, click the context menu of the indicator you
want to hide from Users.
and select Hide from Users.
A Hidden from Users icon displays next to indicators you have hidden from users. Note: These are global changes
and cannot be customized on a course by course basis. Click User Progress.
Here, you can hide progress indicators from users in the User Progress report.
Click the context menu of an indicator you want to hide
and select Hide from Users.
Brightspace Data Sets version has been updated to 4.0. Included in this update are major changes that remove
and rename columns in existing Brightspace Data Sets. View the Release Notes to see a full list of columns that
have been replaced by new or recently released data sets.
There are two new Brightspace Data Sets. Question Library, details all the questions that have been created
in your organization, and Question Relationships, detail the quizzes, sections and question pools that have
questions added in your organization. Note: The Quiz Questions Brightspace Data Set will be deprecated
in the March 2020 release. This feature implements PIE item D5291.
Instructors grading discussion posts from Grades will now see their evaluation in Discussions.
Note: Existing grade data for discussions are not migrated. This synchronization only occurs for new
grade entries. This feature implements PIE items D3610 and D0391.
Course Admin now features a link to import outcomes into your course. Learning Outcomes can still be
imported using the New Content Experience - Lessons, and outcomes imported in one location will display in
the other. Note: Learning Outcomes may display as Competencies or Standards depending on your
organization's settings.
From Course Administration, click Standards.
Here, you can view existing standards that have been aligned to your course, or import new ones.
The standards import workflow mirrors the existing import workflow in the New Content Experience-Lessons
The Manager Dashboard interface now displays Teams and People labels in the People table that differentiate
between the teams and individual direct reports of managers.
Use Activities in Quick Eval to display a dashboard of pending evaluations organized by activity.
This feature implements PIE item D5475.
In Quick Eval, easily complete all assessments for one activity using the new Activity view.
Activities display when there is an unevaluated submission, or no submissions in the activity.
Activities display indicators to identify new submissions, and show the progress of learner submissions,
completed evaluations and published feedback.
Hover your mouse over the indicators...
To evaluate all submissions, review the submission list, or publish all feedback.
The d2l.Tools.Quizzes.RoundingLogicUpdateconfiguration variable is now on by default for all users.
Arithmetic and Significant Figures questions now round up from 0.5. This feature implements PIE item D1751.
A new Completed content topic release condition has been introduced.
The method of completion for Completed contenttopic depends on the type, such as viewing
a file or submitting an assignment. Optionalcontent topics can trigger this release condition,
and this condition ignores exemptions, meaningthe condition can be met regardless of the
activity being required, option or exempt.
The Visual Table of Contents will now display the optimal number of modules in the widget,
and has introduced paging.
Want to learn more about the Activity view in Quick Eval? Check out our new video,
and don't forget to subscribe!

title: Quizzes - Manually Grade a Quiz - Instructor

captions.text: Manually grade quiz responses, question byquestion, to maintain consistency in assessments.
This tutorial shows how to manually gradea quiz.
To begin, from Quizzes, click the contextmenu of the quiz you want to grade…
and select Grade.You are presented with three grading options
separated by tabs: grade by User, grade byAttempts,and grade by Questions.
For this example, to maintain consistencyin your grading, click Questions.
When grading individual responses, you canremove user details from each question by
setting Blind Marking. If View Graded Responsesis selected the questions that have already
been graded by the system or another instructordisplay.
For this example, select Blind Marking.Navigate to the question you want to evaluate…
and click it.Review each attempt, and input a score.
Then, to proceed to the next attempt, clickSave and Continue.
Continue this process of inputting gradesfor each attempt, as required.
When the final attempt is graded, click Save.You are returned to the Questions tab to continue
this process.Manually grade quiz responses, question by
question, to maintain consistency in assessments.

title: Assignments - Submit and Confirm a Submission - Learner

captions.text: Complete assessments and activities usingAssignments.
This tutorial shows how to submit and confirman assignment submission.
From Assignments, you can preview the assignmentsyou will submit to your course instructor,
the score you achieve, the submission youmake, the feedback from your instructor, and
the due date, which is the submission deadlinefor an assignment in your course.
End dates are attached to Assignments
The end date is the final date an Assignment is available for you to
submit assignments to, regardless of the duedate.
To begin, from Assignments, select the assignment you want to submit your work to.
Review the instructions provided by your instructor.
Note: Your instructor will provide detailed instructions for completing the assignment,
read this carefully before starting your work
Then, in the Submit Assignment section, click Add a File...
...and browse to the file you want to submit.
You can attach files from your local computeror storage device, a personal locker, a group
locker or Brightspace ePortfolio.For this example, we will select a file from
My Computer.Drag...
...and drop a file onto the upload target.When you are ready, click Add.
A summary of the file you are uploading appears.
Next, enter any comments you want to submit with the file.
You may be required to submit an assignment as a text submission.
To do this, complete your work in the rich text editor.
Some assignments do not require a submission.
Your instructor may require to indicate your assignment has been completed.
In this case, you will see Mark as Complete. Click it before the assignment due date
to indicate you have completed the work.
Note: if Mark as Complete is not available to you, no additional action is required.
When you are ready, click Submit.
Review the assignment submission. This may display differently depending on the assignment type.
Then, click Done.
This returns you to Assignments.
Here you can confirm that a submission was made.
In the submissions column, if you see one or more submissions has been made, and you can select it
Then the file has been submitted successfully. Click a submission...
...to view the history, which includes the submitted files and the associated dates,
Click the drop down to view other assignment submissions, click the submitted file...
...and open it to review your submission.
Complete assessments and activities using Assignments.

title: Google Apps™ Widget - Add Google Apps Widget to a Course Offering - Instructor

captions.text: Add the Google Apps Service to a course offeringso instructors and learners can conveniently
access their recent emails, documents, andupcoming events.
This tutorial shows how to add the GoogleApps widget to a course offering.
To begin, from Homepages, click the activehomepage.
For this example, we will edit the Astronomy101 homepage.
Navigate to the Widgets section.
This section provides a mock-up of the homepagelayout with options to add widgets.
For this example, we want to add the GoogleApps widget preceding the Announcements widget.
Click Add Widgets.
The Access Google Apps widget provides linksto email, calendar, and docs, and indicates
the number of unread email messages.
The Google Apps widget provides the user withdirect access to recent emails, documents,
and upcoming events.
Select Google Apps from the list of widgetsand click Add.
Rearrange the widget by dragging and droppingit in the desired location.
Then, click Save and Close to add the widgetto the homepage.
Your default homepage is now updated.
Use the Google Apps widget to access recentemails, upcoming events, and documents.
If the widget does not connect with a GoogleApps account, contact your administrator.
Add the Google Apps Service to a course offeringso instructors and learners can conveniently
access their recent emails, documents, andupcoming events.

title: Release Highlights - October 2017 (version 10.7.6) - Administrator

captions.text: This video highlights some of the new andimproved features of Brightspace Learning
Environment 10.7.6.Instructors can now create and schedule posts
ahead of time in the Activity Feed widgetthat appear to leaners at a specified date
and time.Once you have crafted a post in the Activity
Feed, click Post Later.Set the date and time for the post to appear
to learners...and click Schedule Post.
Then, click Save.You can also review scheduled posts. To do
so, click Planned Posts...which gives an overview of all pending communications,
click a posts context menu...to edit or delete it.
You can now turn on new configuration variablethat allows you to set the default state of
new assignment submission folders to eitherHidden or Visible
This feature implements PIE item D4080.The new configuration variable, d2l.Tools.Dropbox.NewFolderVisibility,
allows you to choose the default visibilitystate for new assignment submission folders.
To change the current default from hiddento visible, click Edit.
Click the Org Value dropdown...and select Visible.
Then, click Save.Parents are now better informed about upcoming
work because Brightspace for Parents now displaysupcoming quizzes that have an end date.
The Upcoming Assignments widget has been renamedthe Upcoming Work widget.
Upcoming Quizzes with an end date will nowdisplay in the Upcoming Work widget. Parents
can differentiate quizzes at a glance by observingthe Quiz icon, or the assignment type.
Brightspace for Parents is now releasing withlimited availability to clients in Ireland,
Australia, and Singapore.Brightspace Portfolio is now available in
AWS Regions EU and Asia Pacific. It is notrecommended that clients use both Brightspace
Portfolio and ePortfolio concurrently.Instructors can now link content stored in
their Google Drive™ or OneDrive™ accounts directlyinto the Content tool; doing so will automatically
update the files' permissions to view only.The Google Drive and One Drive options are
available for Activity Feed, Portfolio, Assignments,Lessons, Content and the Quicklinks Picker.
These features can be turned off with configvariables: d2l.3rdParty.GoogleDrive.EnableGooglePicker,
d2l.3rdParty.OneDrive.EnableOneDrivePickerFrom the
content tool, click Existing Activities...and select Google Drive or OneDrive. For this
example, select Google Drive.The files and folders stored in your Google
Drive will display. Select the file you willlink to the Content tool...
...and click Select.Your newly added material displays at the
bottom of your module in Content.Organizations using the standard data export
customization will now only see section enrollmentinformation in their exports.
Administrators and instructors with the properpermissions can now change a course image
directly from the My Courses widget, or theexisting image banner of a course.
Note: The See Course Info and the Change CourseImage permissions are required to access the
Change Image option.Once the permissions are assigned to the appropriate
roles, from the My Courses widget, click MoreActions.
Then, select Change Image.Choose the image from a library of existing
images or upload a custom image.Instructors can now launch the Bulk edit exemptions
page from a Grade Item or Grade Category page.From the Manage Grades page in the Grades
tool, click the context menu of a grade item...and select Enter Grades.
A new context menu appears next to a learner'sname. Click it...
and select Bulk edit exemptions...to view and manage a learner's exemptions.
Instructors can now link to specific locations(units, lessons, and materials) in the Lessons
tool using a unique URL.Instructors can now create new documents,
and edit or delete existing ones using theHTML editor within the Lessons tool.
From within a lesson in the Lessons tool,click Add Material.
Then, select the new Document option.Enter a title...
and content. When using the HTML editor, aquicklinks bar displays. This quicklinks bar
can be docked using the Open In Full Screenicon.
Click save to make your new material availableto learners.

title: Release Highlights - July 2021 (v 20.21.7)

captions.text: This feature highlights some of the new and updated features of Brightspace Learning Environment 20.21.7
The new assignment creation experience now supports categories.
When it is enabled, instructors can add new or existing assignment categories when creating or editing a new assignment.
To enable: Ensure that the d2l.Tools.Activities.SetCategoriesOnEdit (OrgUnit) configuration variable is set to On.
This feature implements PIE item D6656.
To create the category, access Assignments.
Click Edit Categories
Add Category
Enter a Name for your category
And then click Create
This release adds the following new columns to Learner Usage ADS to the Data hub.

LastQuizAttemptDateLastScormCompletionDate
LastScormVisitDate
The d2l.Tools.MyCoursesWidget.UpdatedSortLogic configuration variable has now reached end-of-life status and no longer appears in the Config Variable Browser.
With this change, the My Courses Widget now uses only the Updated Sort Logic setting by default.
To reduce redundancy in the Quizzes tool, the Introduction field has been removed.
When an instructor edits a quiz, the Introduction field is no longer available.
If any quiz previously had text in the Introduction field, on clicking Edit, the text is automatically appended to the Description field.
The Report Setup tab on the Edit Quiz page is now available on the context menu of a quiz and reads as Setup Reports.
Note: you must have the Manage Quiz Reports permission is enabled for the instructor role.
When setting an enforced time limit for a quiz, instructors can now set the grace period for a quiz to 0 minutes, in place of the default grace period setting of 5 minutes.
This feature implements PIE item D516.
For quizzes that contain questions that need to be manually scored (such as Written Response questions)
AND that have the "Allow attempt to be set as graded immediately upon completion" option disabled,
a new Pending Evaluation status appears beside the quiz attempt on the Grade Quiz page.
The Can Edit Config Variable Values permission under Roles and Permissions > Config Variable Browser now reads as Can See and Edit Config Variable Values.
Also note that a select all check box has been added to the Edit Permissions page to enable you to select or de-select the permissions in an entire row.
This feature implements PIE items D6258, D253, and D2080.
The d2l.Tools.Rubrics.CreateExperienceOptIn configuration variable is now set to ON for all clients and can no longer be changed to opt out of the new experience.

title: Brightspace Portfolio - Bring Your Own Device - Learner

captions.text: Collect evidence of your learning to sharewith others by adding the Brightspace Portfolio
app to your personal device. This tutorialshows how to connect the Brightspace Portfolio
app on your personal device to your Brightspaceaccount and then collect and share evidence.
This process has three steps. Downloadingthe Brightspace Portfolio app from your devices'
app store, copying, or printing, the log indetails, and making the connection on your
device.To find the log in details, from My Portfolio,
click Log into the App.A pop-up displays with log in details. You
can copy or type your institution's web address,or print and scan the QR code attached to
your institution.Next, from your device, open the Brightspace
Portfolio app and select my device.Enter the web address of your institution,
or scan the QR code found in the Log intoBrightspace Portfolio App window.
Then, enter the same credentials you use tolog into your courses.
and select Log In.Brightspace Portfolio is ready for evidence
collection. You can take a new photo, recorda video, or upload a file already on your
device.Once you have captured the evidence, select
Collected Evidence to edit or upload it.Select the evidence you want to review.
Here, you can add a title, an audio reflectionor type some thoughts before uploading the
evidence. Select Add a title...Enter a title, and select Done.
When you are ready, select Upload.Then, select which
course the evidence will be associated with.
Collect evidence of your learning to share
with others by adding the Brightspace Portfolio add to your personal device.

title: Awards - Revoke an Award - Instructor

captions.text: Revoke an award if it has been issuedin error or if an award recipient no longer
meets the award criteria. This tutorial shows how to revoke an award that has been issued to a leaner.
To begin, from Awards, select the user whose award you want to revoke. Then, click Revoke.
Select the award to revoke fromthe Select an Award dropdown. Next, provide
context as to why the award is being revokedin the Revoke Reason. Lastly, click Revoke.
The learners award is revoked. Revoke an awardif it has been issued in error or if an award
recipient no longer meets the award criteria.

title: Quizzes - Attach a Release Condition to a Quiz - Instructor

captions.text: Customize learners’ learning paths by attachingrelease conditions that learners must satisfy
before they can access a quiz.This tutorial shows how to attach a release
condition to a quiz.From Manage Quizzes, select the quiz to which
you want to attach the release condition.And click the Restrictions tab.
In the Additional Release Conditions section,you can attach an existing release condition
or create and attach a new release condition.You can also remove one or all attached release
conditions.For this example, we will create and attach
a release condition.To create your new release condition, set
the condition type and details.Click the Select Condition Type menu...
And select the desired condition from themenu.
For this example, we want to release the quizto learners when they complete a checklist
item.In the Condition Details section, select the
checklist that is associated with the condition.Click Select Checklist...
and select the checklist that you want toassociate with the release condition.
For this example, we will select ActivityChecklist, which contains a list of activities
that must be completed throughout the course.Click Select Checklist to specify the checklist
item that you will associate with the condition.For this example, select What Makes Aurorae.
Once you've applied the release condition,learners must complete this item before they
can view the Auroral quiz.When you are satisfied with the release condition,
click Create.When you are ready, click Save and Close.
Attach a release condition to a quiz to helplearners sufficiently prepare for the assessment.

title: Brightspace Insights™ - Manipulate Data in the Engagement Dashboard - Administrator

captions.text: Assess and monitor engagement metrics acrossyour organization to identify levels of user
engagement and recognize successful behaviors.This tutorial shows how to view and manipulate
the data available in the Engagement Dashboard.To begin, from Insights Portal, click the
Engagement Dashboard.The Engagement Dashboard provides interactive
data visualizations for Last Course Access,Status of Assignments with Due Dates, Time
in Content, and Time in Content versus GradeEach visualization can be viewed as a table,
to change your view, click the table icon.Data in the engagement visualizations can
also be exported, click Export...And select the desired output format. To return
to the data, click Close.To cycle through available sorting options
for each visualization, click Sort.Select a date range from the Last Course Access
visualization...To view a breakdown of user roles who accessed
the course, or not, during that time.To view which courses the users with that
role are enrolled in, click a role.You can further drill into the data, select
a course.To view the users who have the previously
selected role, who were active during theselected time.
This granular data includes username, firstand last name, email address for easy action
and date the course was last accessed if applicable.The Status of Assignments with Due Date
visualization only includes assignments withdue dates for users with the Can Submit permission.
Click a completion stage...To view the course offerings to which the
assignments belong. Click the course offering...To view granular data including user name,
preferred first and last name, email, assignmentID and name...
completion date if applicable, assignment due date, assignment type and assignment score if applicable.
Navigate to Time in Content.The Time in Content Distribution visualization
displays the total time each user has spentin each course, rounded to the next full minute,
in a histogram with 10 data buckets.To remove a role from the visualization, click
the role in the legend.To view a breakdown of the courses users with
a specific role belong to, select the roleand time from the histogram.
Click on a course...To view the users in the selected course offering
from the roles and time previously selected.For each user their time in content is compared
to the average time in content for other userswith the same role and their current final
grade.Click a user to view a breakdown of the content
modules and topics they spent their time in.Click a content module to view a breakdown
of the visited topics.Lastly, the Tine in Content versus Grade visualization
shows a breakdown of how long each user spendsin each courses content in comparison with
their current final grade.Hover over a point in the scatterplot...
to view a user’s username, preferred name,current final grade and a time in content
summary. You can click the point in the scatterplotto view detailed information regarding the
user’s specific time in content modulesand topics across all of their active courses.
Assess and monitor engagement metrics acrossyour organization to identify levels of user
engagement and recognize successful behaviors.

title: Rubrics - Create a Holistic Rubric - Instructor

captions.text: Create and use holistic rubrics to evaluatelearners based on a single criterion.
This tutorial shows how to create a holisticrubric.
To begin, from Rubrics, click New Rubric.
Enter a name for your rubric.
Rubrics autosaves your changes.
Change the status of your Rubric if necessary.For this example, keep the default, Published.
To make your rubric holistic, click the RubricType menu...
... and select Holistic.
Select your scoring method. Scoring methodsinclude: No
Score or Percentages. In this example, wewill use the default Percentages method.
You can reverse the order in which the levelsdisplay. Add new levels using Add new level
before or Add new level after, respectively,at any time. To remove a level, click
Delete level.
Edit the level titles.
Next, update the level percentages, and adddetails to inform learners how to achieve
each level of the rubric.When adding rubric details you will be able
to include basic HTML mark up, such as bold,italics and unordered lists.
Navigate to Initial Feedback
Next, add initial feedback if desired.
Then, confirm additional rubric options.
Update the Rubric Visibility if necessary.
Select Hide scores from students, to hidestudents’ points value if you use a different
grade scheme.
Enter a description for the rubric for yourpersonal reference.
Edit Advanced Availability to change associationswith Competencies and ePortfolio.
When you are ready, click Close.
Your rubric displays.
Create and use holistic rubrics to evaluatelearners based on a single criterion.

title: Google Apps™ Widget - Configure the Google Apps Widget Settings - Administrator

captions.text: Configure settings in the Google Apps administrationarea to define document submission and provisioning
user settings.
This tutorial shows how to configure settingsin the Google Apps administration area.
To begin, from Google Apps Administration,navigate to the Settings page.
You can automatically authenticate your GoogleApps for Education account using the Client
ID and secret.
After setting your ID, you do not need anyadditional intervention to access the account.
In the Tab Visibility section, you can decidewhich tabs are shown (or hidden) in the Google
Apps widget.
For this example, we will show all of thepotential tabs: Mail, Google Calendar, and
Google Drive.
In the Document Submission Options, you candetermine whether Google Documents are exported
as their original file type, or as PDF files.
For this example, we will enable Export asPDF.
If you want to limit access to the GoogleDirectory API, select Read-only access to
the Google Directory API checkbox.
Enabling this setting removes the Create NewUser, Suspend Accounts, and Restore Accounts
options on the Google Apps AdministrationManage Users page.
Provisioning User Settings controls what theuser can do to set up a Google Apps account.
"Create Account" allows users to create andlink a Google Apps account to an organization
account.
"Create Link" allows users to link an existingGoogle Apps account to their organization
account.
"No Access" means that only administratorsare able to create or link organization user
accounts to Google Apps accounts.
To update the Google Apps settings, clickSave.
Your settings are now saved.
Configure settings in the Google Apps administrationarea to define document submission and provisioning
user settings.

title: Question Library - Create an arithmetic question - Instructor

captions.text: Be ready to assess learners’ understandingof number concepts by creating and storing
arithmetic questions in Question Library.This tutorial shows how to create an arithmetic
question in Question Library.To begin, from the Quizzes tool, click Question
Library.Click New . . .
. . . and select Arithmetic Question.Give your question a title, if desired. The
title displays in the question list in QuestionLibrary.
Then, enter the number of points you wantthe question to be worth.
Enter your problem in the Question Text field.If you want to generate random numbers for
your problem, enclose the variables in curlybraces.
Enter the solution to your problem in theformula field. Be sure to enclose all variables
in curly braces.You can also refine answer criteria for your
arithmetic question.Answer Precision is where you set the acceptable
number of decimal places the answer must contain.In the Tolerance section, you can decide if
you will accept near-accurate, estimated,or rounded answers.
You can ask learners to provide the unitsto a question in the Units section.
We do not require these fields for our samplequestion, so we will leave them blank.
Next, enter the variables you used in yourquestion. For each variable, you can provide
a minimum and maximum value, as well as includedecimal places or add a step value. A step
value sets increments for the minimum andmaximum values you choose for your variables.
For example, a step value of 5 would onlychoose variables that are increments of 5,
such as 5, 10, 15, or 20. For this question,we will leave the decimal places and step
fields blank, but enter a minimum of 1 anda maximum of 10 for each variable.
Click Add Variable to include another variable.Preview how your question will display to
learners by clicking Preview.Click Done when you are ready to exit the
preview.When you are satisfied with your question,
click Save.Your question is saved in Question Library.
Be ready to assess learners’ understandingof number concepts by creating and storing
arithmetic questions in Question Library.

title: Fundamentals - Edit a Config Variable - Administrator

captions.text: Set configuration variables to define howspecific tools should operate for a user,
role, org unit (such as a course offering),or organization.
This tutorial shows how to edit a configuration variable.
To begin, from the Config Variable Browser,navigate to the variable you want to edit.
For this example, we will expand the Toolscategory...
...and click Classlist from the list of tools.
Next, click the variable you want to edit.
For this example, we will edit the DisplayProfileImagevariable.
Here, you can review the properties, whichinclude data type and system value,...
...and override values, which apply a datatype and system value to a specific org unit.
To add an override value, click Add Value.
You are then prompted to define the overridevalues.
If you know the Org Unit ID of the org unityou want to modify, you can enter it in the
field provided.
Otherwise, click Select Org unit to searchor browse for an org unit.
You can use the search field to locate a specificorg unit or browse the list of org unit.
For this example, we will select AdvancedCritical Thinking.
Then, click Update.
Next, we will define the value.
For this example, we will turn the variableoff.
Click Save to add the variable value to theoverride list.
With this override value in place, the profileimage will not display for the specified classlist.
However, the profile image will appear forall other course offering org units in the
organization.
Set configuration variables to define howspecific tools should operate for a user,
role, org unit (such as a course offering),or organization.
